TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the government's intention to further tax workers with a compulsory superannuation levy of three per cent. The minister is no doubt aware that ACOSS calculates that this levy will cost an individual worker on average earnings $16 a week and a couple with children on the median income $20 a week. I ask: have you or your department assessed ACOSS's calculations? Has the government estimated the impact on families of another tax hike? Would you inform us of any studies you have instigated regarding the consequences of this further tax levy on individuals and families?

—This question, dealing with matters of tax, is just as properly directed to my colleague Senator Cook. In terms of what this government has done for families, we stand absolutely and very proudly on our commitment to families and to enabling families to have sufficient income. The best way we have done that is by the Working Nation statement and job creation. There is absolutely no doubt that that is the preferred way of creating income security for families and ongoing income to enable families to make those choices. When you add that to our policies through social security for targeted and directed payments to families, you see that we have nothing to blush about at all in terms of families. As to proposals about taxation and any of the suggestions you have talked about—that is, superannuation and so on—that is a good trawl for what might or might not be in the budget. I am certainly not going to add to speculation.

—Minister, I am not asking you to add to speculation. We want to know what contribution you have been making to this debate by assessing the impact upon families of the government's proposed superannuation levy. Everyone knows that the government is considering in depth a tax hike in the form of a superannuation levy. What we want is not speculation on what might happen; we want to know whether you have been contributing to that debate by assessing the consequences of those proposals on families. Have you done that work?

—It does not matter how differently or elegantly you put it, it is still a trawl about what might or might not be in the budget. As to how this government deals with family policy, it is not the purview or the responsibility of only one ministry; any number of ministries in this government look at the impact on families. So, Senator, wait and see.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Last week the media reported on the release by the minister of a discussion paper on the Australian trade framework. I understand the document, titled Winning markets: the next step, will be circulated broadly to Australian industry and unions for comment. Will the minister elaborate on the purpose of this exercise and what he intends to gain from it?

—Senator Jones is, of course, correct that last week I released to the Trade Policy Advisory Council, which is the peak industry advisory group in the Trade portfolio, the discussion paper Winning markets: the next step. It was only the first step in an extensive process of consultation that I intend to undertake with Australian business, unions and interest groups on Australia's trade policy into the future. The next step will involve round table meetings in state capitals over the next month and consultations with peak organisations, such as the National Farmers Federation, the ACTU, the BCA and the ACCI. It is important that we do have this consultation, that we do give a range of people an opportunity to contribute, because winning markets is at the heart of Australia's economic future.

PARA.TAB: Like all policy papers, this is not trying to cover every issue that might ever influence our trade performance, because that ranges much too broadly for any one useful consultative exercise. This is about the international trade setting. It is not about the relevant and equally important but separate issues of domestic industry policy and domestic economic settings. It is not intended to cover the waterfront of all the issues relating to trade policy. It focuses on the overseas policy environment and how we should best respond to the dramatic changes which are taking place and how we can best use Australia's diplomatic and other resources to influence that environment to win markets for Australian companies.

There have been some major changes, of course, in the last few years and Australia has made, I think it is widely regarded and accepted, a very effective contribution to those changes. I refer in particular to the outcome of the Uruguay Round and to the implementation of APEC, both of which Senator Jones is interested in. The discussion paper is about building on those achievements and establishing a framework to guide Australia's trade and investment activities well into the next century.

The changes that are taking place in the international trading environment, for example, are the increase in regionalism and the increasing global activity of major corporations, both of which are making the policies of the past no longer necessarily relevant, and we need to review them. We want this process of consultation to be a two-way street. I want to hear what industry has to say about the trade policy framework that we need to have in place to win markets for Australian companies into the next century, but I also want to take the opportunity to broaden and deepen the understanding of the Australian community, and specifically Australian industry and workers, of the very central place of trade policy in Australia's economic welfare. I want to have industries' plans and interests underpinning what we do to provide the best conditions for them, but I also want to communicate to the Australian private sector that it is very important that it focuses on international exports in its corporate plans.

More and more Australian companies are exporting, but it is still the biggest problem in our trade performance that not enough companies export. Many companies which are capable of exporting are not doing so—more than ever before, a higher proportion than ever before, but not enough. Therefore, the overriding purpose of the dialogue with industry is to develop a dynamic and proactive trade policy setting that will ensure Australia's future as a trading nation, because our economic performance broadly continues to be limited and affected by the extent to which we can be a successful trading nation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to the likely collapse of the Baring Brothers Bank because of the capacity of one rogue employee to make bad investments on the derivatives market. Given that a similar situation here in Australia cost AWA some $50 million back in 1986, can the minister outline how exposed we in Australia are to a collapse occurring here? Is the minister aware of and concerned by a Price Waterhouse study just last year which found that fewer than half of the organisations dealing in corporative derivatives had proper systems to monitor their processes? Does the minister agree that the response of the Australian Securities Commission to call for a voluntary disclosure code for non-bank derivatives traders is an inadequate response to the risk posed by rogue traders to Australia?

—I do have some information from the Attorney-General in respect of this particular problem. He advises that, at this stage, he does not have full details of the nature of the collapse. However, he has been advised by the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission that the commission has been assessing as a matter of urgency the collapse and whether that collapse is likely to have an adverse implication for Australian markets. The advice that the Attorney has received from the chairman of the ASC is that the collapse is unlikely to have any significant market effects in Australia.

PARA.TAB: You are right, Senator Kernot: following news of the Barings collapse, the ASC did issue a press statement on 27 February reaffirming its concerns, with a lack of explicit financial reporting requirements in Australia, about derivatives for non-bank disclosing entities. It did cite in support of its statement a corporate derivative survey released by the Australian Society of Corporate Treasurers and Price Waterhouse in September 1994, a survey to which you referred. That survey raised concerns about a sizeable gap between treasury staff knowledge and senior management knowledge of derivatives.

I am advised that there are already mechanisms in place. There are safeguards against fraudulent and excessively risky derivatives trading on market, and they are provided by the Sydney Futures Exchange and the Australian Stock Exchange procedures. Amongst the procedures relevant, there are procedures that provide that all traders of derivative products on market are required to be licensed by the ASC. Licensing requirements include proven financial standing and competency expertise to advise on the use of these products as well as standards of honesty and integrity. The procedures involve proper disclosure of the nature of particular transactions. That nature will be given to investors. Fidelity funds provided by the Australian Stock Exchange and SFE are maintained to meet claims by investors in the case of dealer default. As well as that, there are internal procedures for fair and orderly conduct of the market to enable margin calls to be made by the Sydney Futures Exchange.

I am advised that this is also supported by requirements for traders to report all transactions daily to the relevant exchange. That reporting process can immediately identify trends and risks and, in particular, the need for the exchange to take immediate action to protect the integrity of the market.

As well as that, I think the ASC noted in this regard that a proposed Australian accounting standard dealing with the financial instruments is being developed. That instrument calls for corporate managers to throw their weight behind development of a voluntary code to meet true and fair disclosure requirements pending the finalisation of the standard. The Attorney sees this as a welcome initiative from the ASC, demonstrating an awareness of, and sensitivity to, the regulatory challenges faced by the greater use of derivatives by corporations.

The other point I should make with respect to this is that the issue of effective regulation and supervision of the derivatives industry is also currently under close consideration by the Australian Council of Financial Supervisors, which includes the Reserve Bank, the Australian Securities Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, established under the Australian Securities Commission Act. So, all in all, there are systems in place and systems are being developed. I suspect that this does not fully answer Senator Kernot's question. To the extent that it does not, I will bring it to the notice of the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I further ask: would you agree that Australia's very high current account and high public debt mean that we are quite exposed? Do you remember that up to May last year we were told that it would be impossible for all our superannuation funds to collectively lose billions of dollars on the bond market, but it happened? Basically, are you sure it cannot happen here?

—I am not sure it is not going to rain tomorrow, either. I am sure you are not expecting me to give that sort of answer. What we are saying is that on the basis of the advice received by the government today, on the basis of the mechanisms in place, there are mechanisms aimed at protecting and safeguarding the system against it happening within Australia. If you go on to draw inferences from current account situations and so on, I think one needs to look at the reality of the situation facing all countries in terms of flows of money into and out of those countries. Though we are in the ball game for funds, I must say that in the international perspective we are very much one of the smaller players. As I said, I will pass on the purport of your question to the Attorney-General.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that earlier today the minister was involved in signing two bilateral sporting agreements with the visiting French Minister for Youth and Sport, Madame Michele Alliot-Marie. Can the minister outline to the Senate the nature and importance of these agreements?

—Australia and France have a had a very good sporting relationship for a number of years. This morning I was pleased to formalise that relationship on behalf of the government. Two agreements were signed. The first was a bilateral sports agreement to enable the two governments to encourage and facilitate exchanges of sporting teams, coaches, sport scientists, administrators and other practitioners. This program will be conducted jointly by the Australian Sports Commission and the French Ministry of Youth and Sports.

PARA.TAB: The first activity under the program will be a $10,000 sports sciences scholarship sponsored by the Australia-France Foundation. Under this scholarship, one staff member of the sports sciences division of the Australian Sports Commission will work at the equivalent body within the French ministry for a period of three months. As well, France is looking to tap into Australia's expertise in a range of sports, including hockey, yachting and cycling; sports for people with a disability, particularly our AussieAble program; children's sport and our AussieSport program.

In addition, my French counterpart, the Minister for Youth and Sport, Madame Alliot-Marie, signed an anti-doping agreement. France now joins Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom, Norway and New Zealand as signatories to this agreement which embraces the reciprocal development and enforcement of measures against doping in sport. France is one of the leading anti-doping nations in Europe, and its considerable knowledge and expertise will be immensely valuable to the anti-doping agreement and its programs.

I emphasis the point that Australia will continue to strongly pursue the international fight against drugs. The government will take up every opportunity to progress anti-doping issues on the international stage, and we are very pleased that France is joining us and the other multilateral partners in this agreement. I believe, and I hope that all senators would agree, that this is a very important endeavour. I think it is patently clear that, by formalising our sporting relationships with France through these two agreements signed today, the sportsmen and sportswomen of both countries will benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the application to allow the release of contaminated water from retention pond 2 at ERA's Ranger mine into the river system of Kakadu National Park. I ask, one, is it correct that Ranger uranium mine was designed with a no release system so as to protect the surrounding area from the harmful effects of the pollutants produced during the mining and milling processes at the mine? Two, does the minister agree that the proposal would significantly weaken the environmental safeguards that are in place to protect the Kakadu world heritage area? Three, if so, what action will the minister take to ensure the release of the water does not go ahead? Four, if not, on what factual basis does the minister form his view?

—The operator of the Ranger uranium mine, Energy Resources of Australia, has applied to Northern Territory authorities to release water from retention pond No. 2, which is in the restricted release zone. Since mining began, release of water has been limited to the non-restricted release zone; that is, non-contaminated water. Apart from minor accidental spills, shown by the Supervising Scientist to have had negligible environmental impact, restricted release zone water has not been released into Magela Creek in the mine's 15 years of operation.

PARA.TAB: The Fox report into the Ranger uranium mine recognised that some water release would be required during the life of the mine. The mine was not designed to have a no-release management system. The current wet season at Ranger has been the wettest on record and retention ponds there are filled to capacity. Calculations indicate that a wet season the likes of which occurs once in 100 years may be occurring in that area.

In 1989, the government agreed that for very wet seasons—on average, one every 10 years—the controlled release of water constituted best practicable technology and should not cause any harm to the environment, provided appropriate conditions were met, such as a minimum creek flow for dilution purposes, a dilution level of water to be based on biological and chemical tests, and a suitable monitoring program in force throughout the release. Any water release from Ranger will be diluted such that the water quality downstream of the mine will not be significantly different from the quality of the natural water.

Extensive testing by the Environment Research Institute of the Supervising Scientist shows that water released from Ranger will not harm the natural ecosystem or pose a threat to the health of people living or gathering foods downstream of the mine. It therefore, I believe, does not weaken in any way the safeguards that protect the Kakadu world heritage area.

The Supervising Scientist has provided advice to the Northern Territory as to conditions under which he considers the proposed release would not have significant environmental impacts. The final decision concerning the application by ERA to release water from Ranger mine in fact rests with the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true that the mine cannot function without the frequent release of contaminated water from the site? What action does the minister intend taking to protect the environment at Kakadu from the radioactive accumulation in the land, water and food chain? The minister has talked about a monitoring program. How will that monitoring program assess the effect on those features—the land, the water and the food chain—and on the people in that area?

—I indicated in my earlier answer to Senator Chamarette's question that this is a unique occurrence, so I do not believe the premise of her supplementary question can in fact be sustained. I am happy to seek more advice through the Office of the Supervising Scientist as to the nature of that monitoring program and will provide that information to her in due course. Obviously it is a complex issue, but I am sure we can provide more details as to monitoring and the scientific assessments that are undertaken by the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Human Services. I refer her to the minister for health's recent comments that there is presently an oversupply of general practitioners in Australia. Surely it is more correct to say that there is a major maldistribution of GPs so that the larger population areas are very well serviced while many regional and remote Australians still find it very difficult to get the access to the family doctor that city dwellers take for granted. Can the minister explain why, after 12 years in office, the government's general practice initiatives for regional Australia, including relocation and training assistance and the practice grants scheme, have been so unsuccessful? What specific new plans does the government have to address this worsening problem for regional Australia?

—You cannot conclude that because there is a maldistribution there is not an oversupply. On the figures—and I do not have them to hand; I will certainly see if I can find them for you—compared to other countries and per head of population you could clearly argue that Australia has an oversupply of general practitioners. But there is no doubt—I think it is very well understood and I have certainly said it in this place before—that there is a very distinct maldistribution of those general practitioners.

PARA.TAB: The points you raise are entirely right. It is very difficult to get a sufficient number of GPs to work in rural Australia, particularly remote rural Australia. That is why the government has, over the last few years, instituted a number of processes to make every effort to encourage general practitioners to take the opportunity to do their general practice in rural and remote Australia.

There are a number of initiatives and they are already beginning to make some difference. Clearly not enough difference—and again I can check those figures for you—but there has been a number of doctors who have taken up the resettlement packages and the financial assistance the government provides to doctors to help with the cost of moving into the country.

There are two other areas that I think are a continuing matter for discussion between rural general practitioners and the government. One is the need perhaps to change undergraduate training and certainly post-graduate training for general practitioners so that they have a different confidence about dealing with a number of the processes and procedures they may face in the country, which has been said to be one of the reasons for a lot of general practitioners not wanting to go to the country.

The other area of particular concern is the locum arrangements. How does a general practitioner get any rest, relief or break from the practice if they cannot find a locum service? Both of those are matters of concern and discussion between government and the general practitioners, particularly rural general practitioners. It is important to know that the problem is well recognised by government. The assistance and particularly the significant contribution—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same old story—one of continuing failure.

—Significant contribution, Senator Hill, is not only recognised but addressed by the rural redirection package and the figures that already indicate that a number of doctors have taken up that initiative, that financial assistance to go to rural and remote areas. I will find those figures for you about the number of doctors who have taken those packages and, again, the initiatives by government in working closely with the rural general practitioner associations about training, not only undergraduate training but also in-service training, and practice grants to assist further that distribution.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to reports that over 150 Australian companies are travelling to Germany to participate in next week's computer and communications exhibition at Hanover—CeBIT 95. Is the minister able to confirm that this is the world's largest, most influential and most respected exhibition for this industry, with over 6,000 exhibitors and an expected three-quarters of a million visitors? More importantly, can the minister advise the Senate of the role assigned to Australia as the CeBIT partner country, the opportunities this presents for Australian IT companies and what support, if any, the government has provided to Australian exhibitors at CeBIT 95?

—I thank Senator Loosley for his question. It is true that the CeBIT fair in Hanover is the world's biggest trade fair in information technology and in telecommunications technology and therefore is a prime target in the promotion of Australia's capability in those fields. As Senator Loosley has said in his question, 6,000 exhibitors and three-quarters of a million visitors will go to this fair and it is an ideal opportunity for Australia to market its potential in this vital field and growth area for Australian industry. It is true that each year the organisers of the CeBIT fair select a country partner. In 1995 the country partner is Australia and we will be the focal point of the fair.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, will open the Australian exhibit on the first day of the fair, 8 March. The fair runs from 8 March to 15 March, and 160 Australian information technology companies will attend and exhibit at the fair. These companies will be demonstrating the diversity of Australia's skill and capability in delivering sophisticated, world-class, high-tech solutions for industry. Australia is, of course, a very strong performer in this field.

CeBIT 95 will also present Australia's case for a key investment location in this part of the world. It is not generally realised that Australia's share of the information technology and telecommunications market is, excluding Japan, 50 per cent of all software services in this area of the world—the Asia-Pacific region. We are twice the size of the next largest market, Korea. In the 10 years since 1985, our exports of high technology products have grown by a factor of five—an outstanding achievement for this industry, but even more so for an industry built entirely upon the intelligence and skill of the people who work in it.

The Australian Information Industries Association, which is the industry body for information technology, recently imposed on itself an export target for the industry which, if reached, will see exports of information technology and telecommunications products and services reach $A10 billion by the end of this decade. That will be equivalent to the exports we already have out of this country in coal and iron ore. It is, therefore, interesting to see a highly technological industry creating an export market equivalent to one of the staple commodities—coal and iron ore.

The exhibitors who have made the commitment to participate in this year's fair are to be congratulated for grasping this opportunity. To assist those exhibitors to get their message across, the government has helped to develop the Intelligent Australia CD-ROM and the CeBIT touch screen information system. These products, apart from being excellent examples of leading edge multi-media software, literally place our industry's capability at your fingertips.

The CD-ROM and the touch screen systems were jointly developed by Aspect Computing, my Department of Industry, Science and Technology, the CSIRO and Austrade. The touch screen version, which includes profiles of all CeBIT participants, will be located throughout the Australian exhibition area and will assist vendors to locate the exhibitors they wish to visit.

In addition, to ensure that our message to the world is heard loud and clear, my department has sponsored a hard copy version of our industry capability—the information technology and telecommunications industry capability technology directory. The directory contains 350 of our leading exporters and will be a valuable adjunct to the story we have to tell the world about our high-tech capability. I congratulate all of those people.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I conclude my answer by saying it is a shocking slur on the opposition that its members behave in such a po-faced way about an important Australian industry. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence and relates to the awarding of the overhaul contract for GE404 engines in the RAAF's F18s to Air New Zealand. Is the minister aware that Air New Zealand has recently suffered four engine failures in engines it has overhauled and has been forced to ground 10 of its Boeing 737s as a consequence? What financial penalties are written into the RAAF contract against shoddy workmanship or premature engine failures? Given the fact that the government has transferred a vital defence capability offshore, how is the RAAF to have any surge capacity in an emergency? Air New Zealand demonstrably has none, because it will take until the end of June to overhaul a few engines for its Boeings. Finally, was the RAAF contract in any way a sweetener for the abrogation of the MOU on joint air services between Australia and New Zealand?

—This particular contract went out to tender. Senator MacGibbon would be well aware that, as part of that, New Zealand has taken those tenders in support of Australian defence industry. It is part of the Anzac ship frigate treaty, it is part of closer economic relations—and so that is treated as in the same market. It is always disappointing as an Australian nationalist when an Australian firm does not win. But, of course, on many occasions Australian firms win work under the same conditions from New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: As to the technical capacity of Air New Zealand, that was obviously a matter that the RAAF gave maximum attention to. It had to satisfy itself that Air New Zealand had the capacity technically to be able to deliver on a contract such as this. The main characteristic of the Upper Hunter is that it is excellent country that tends to hold on very well in a drought. The farmers hope it will rain in the next few weeks. The country is good so they can hold on longer than farmers in other areas. When it finally does give way and it is in an area where they cannot feed their stock, they have got to sell off stock at the lowest price in the market. So they are doubly disadvantaged.

The main problem with the government's policy is that it has come up with a number of very crude measures to work out who is in drought that do not take into account the subtleties that I have indicated. One of them is that the gross rainfall pattern in the area does not take into account the way in which rainfall is distributed over time. So what can happen, as did happen in the Upper Hunter, is that some of the areas got a quarter of their annual rainfall in several days. It is an area that is in desperate straits.

There has, fortunately, been assistance from the Fahey government, but in terms of the extreme drought classification, which should be obvious to the minister, this area has been left out again. SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), to a question without notice asked by Senator MacGibbon this day, relating to a contract for engine overhauls between the RAAF and Air New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I raise this matter is that I have genuine concerns about the capability of Air New Zealand to support the RAAF with engine overhauls. It has experienced four failures in recent times of a very old and very reliable engine. The Pratt and Whitney JT8D series of engine, which goes back at least 30 years, is a very simple and robust engine. As long as the engines are properly overhauled and maintained they are utterly reliable, never fail and just keep on going. That is the engine that has made jet travel around the world. To have lost four engines in a short time—engines that were all apparently overhauled by Air New Zealand—is a very worrying situation. Air New Zealand must be very concerned about this because it has grounded 10 of its Boeing 737-200 series, which is a large proportion of its internal fleet.

PARA.TAB: I also have very great concerns about transferring defence resources offshore. I understand what Senator Ray is saying: Australia and New Zealand are now regarded as one market. But I think the government was quite careless and remiss in not thinking through that agreement with respect to what I would call vital assets in defence before it signed. Some things in Australia have to stay within Australia for our own security. Within the commercial support program, the CSP, which transfers maintenance out of the uniformed services into the civilian world, the services retain what they regard as core or essential capabilities. By the same token, there is a real argument to retain some capabilities which we regard as essential within Australia. In a defence emergency, we are the only people who will look after this country. The New Zealanders will not be anywhere in sight.

Another thing that concerns me about Senator Ray's answer—he made this point in answer to Senator Woods, and I have heard him make the same point in numerous estimates hearings—is his comment that Air New Zealand has the capability to undertake these overhauls. I do not doubt that for one moment. It has the potential to do it, but the point is that it is not a reality. What Air New Zealand is dealing with in the JT8D, which it seems to be quite unsuccessful with, is a very old, very simple and robust engine. The engine that we want it to overhaul—the General Electric 404—is a very sophisticated, modern, high performance engine. It is an engine not used in the sedate life of a passenger aircraft with a long life under steady and predictable conditions. It is used in a tactical fighter, which is the most robust environment you can subject any engine to. Both the quality of the engine and the quality of the overhauls and maintenance have to be in the highest order for them to succeed. What Air New Zealand is talking about is potential. All I can say to that is that the road to hell is paved with good intentions.

That leads me to another concern I have with the government. So many of the defence contracts we have seen this government write on major maintenance or in construction areas have been grossly deficient in protecting the interests of the Commonwealth. I do not need to spend much time in the Senate today talking about the huge exposure of the Australian Commonwealth in the Collins submarine program as I have done it so many times in the past. Somewhere near 90 per cent of the contract price has been paid out of about $4 or $5 billion, and we have not yet got one of the ships. The only defence that Senator Ray can offer for that is that the reputation of the prime contractor, a Scandinavian company, is such that it would not want to fail by defaulting on the contract. I can tell Senator Ray that, if there is a default of a few hundred million dollars—let alone a few billion dollars, which may be the exposure ultimately under the Collins contract—the company will walk away from it—but fast. It will blame the Australian government and the Australian Department of Defence for its problems.

I am very concerned about what protection the RAAF and the Department of Defence have in relation to these engines that will be overhauled by Air New Zealand. We had 75 of those aircraft. We have lost two of them, so we now have 73. We probably have a pool of engines approaching 200. In any emergency, we have to know that we can have those engines supported. I believe that it is one of the vital assets that we need in this country to underpin the Australian defence forces. The government ought to revise its policy of transferring those vital assets offshore.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The West Indies Cricket Board of Control
February 22, 1995
Ms Marie Gibbons
Legislation Committee
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Ms Gibbons

The West Indies Cricket Board of Control (WICBC) was made aware of the proposal to amend the Broadcasting Services Act. Since we have a vital interest in the effect this Act has on the WICBC whenever there is an Australian team visiting the West Indies, we have prepared, and we are enclosing a submission which we would like placed before your Legislation Committee.
Yours faithfully
HON. PATRICK H.O. ROUSSEAU, O.J.
CHAIRMAN—MARKETING COMMITTEE
SUBMISSION BY THE WEST INDIES CRICKET BOARD OF CONTROL
RE: THE BROADCASTING SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL 1994

1.When cricket is played internationally, by custom the host country has the sole exclusive rights to the T.V. broadcast. Therefore, the only opportunity the West Indies Cricket Board of Control (WICBC) has to earn substantial income from cricket is during the visit of a touring team to the West Indies whether it be Australia, India or England.

2.The cricket playing nations in the West Indies have a population of 6 million people distributed across 12 territories with only two countries with populations of more than 1 million people, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago. These islands are in various stages of under-development and the experience over the last 50 years of cricket, is that the gate receipts cannot cover the expenses of a tour and the WICBC sustains losses on each and every tour by a visiting team. These losses can run as high as US$400,000.

3.It is only since the advent of T.V. on the tour by England of the West Indies in 1990 that the WICBC has made a profit on a tour. This has been achieved by operating in a free T.V. market in England, Australia, India and Pakistan whenever the teams of those countries are touring the West Indies. By negotiating exclusive deals, we have been able to generate substantial T.V. revenue far in excess of the amounts offered by the state T.V. stations which is the basis of free to air T.V.

4.If the proposed amendment results in the Broadcasting Services Law continuing to apply to our home series cricket against Australia, we would suffer a reduction in the level of the T.V. rights fees, offered by the T.V. stations with whom we now negotiate exclusive positions. 5.Whereas we can appreciate the need to protect national events taking place in Australia, for the viewing public in Australia, it is difficult for us to understand the interference in the right of the WICBC to negotiate the best fees from T.V. for cricket played in the West Indies.
6.The WICBC would consider the inclusion of tours by Australia of the West Indies in the Law Australia an abrogation of the right of the WICBC to negotiate freely in a competitive free trade market.
7.Australia is one of the leading countries in the Commonwealth, and compared with the struggling economies of the English speaking Caribbean, is a highly prosperous country.

The WICBC would hope that rather than pursue a xenophobic policy of conferring benefits on its wealthy consumers at the expense of the development of cricket in the West Indies, it would be high minded and generous enough to modify the Bill, to permit the purchase of television rights in relation to the Australian tour of the West Indies, direct from the Board itself in an open market.
Dated the 22nd Day of February 1995
WEST INDIES CRICKET BOARD OF CONTROL
HON PATRICK H.O. ROUSSEAU, O.J.
CHAIRMAN—MARKETING COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the order of business on the Notice Paper, namely, a motion to give precedence to government business order of the day No. 16, relating to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: If I am successful in having standing orders suspended, it is my intention to move that the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill be called on as the first item of government business today. This is an unusual procedure that has been forced upon the opposition because it seems that the government is abandoning what is an important piece of legislation during the process of that legislation in this place.

PARA.TAB: That bill, as you will remember, Mr Deputy President, was in the committee stage in this chamber before Christmas and then by resolution of this place was taken out into the community through the relevant committee. The committee members of this Senate spent the best part of January visiting indigenous communities throughout Australia conferring upon the amendments that had already been passed and amendments that were foreshadowed and took an enormous amount of very valuable evidence largely confirming the need, which the opposition had suspected, for change to the government's bill. You will remember also, Mr Deputy President, that we have been long arguing the importance of this particular bill to address the primary issues of education, health, housing and jobs for the

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal community and our determination to include appropriate provisions within the bill.

PARA.TAB: I remind you, finally, that in the last sitting fortnight, which was the first sitting fortnight of this year, the committee brought back its report to this parliament. Its report was put down in this place and the whole of Australia as well as this Senate was better informed as a result. Therefore, what we expected in the normal course of events was that the government would then call on its piece of legislation and the debate would continue to finality.

We have reason to believe that the bill will be passed. That has been the success story of the process of amendments through the committee stage. Astonishingly, the government apparently has decided to abandon this process and start it all again at the other end of the building, because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) introduced another bill today arguing that the Senate has failed to pass this bill. He argued that the Senate has failed to pass it, when the government is making a choice of its volition that it not be proceeded with.

The government is not bringing it on, as we have expected and as has appeared in the Notice Paper, and is leaving it to the opposition to bring on the government's own business. We are prepared to do so because we believe bills that are brought to the Senate and that have received the proper attention of the Senate should be debated to their conclusion and, if they can be passed, should be passed.

We are, as I said a few minutes ago, vitally concerned about the deplorable record of education, health, social security, jobs and housing of Aboriginal communities in Australia. Time and time again, statements that must do nothing but embarrass Australia as to the record of this government in a critical area of public policy have been put on the public record.

We want to do something about it. We want to see this bill passed. We have made an enormous effort to put it into a form in which it can be passed. But rather than have it passed and have the government address the amendments of this place, the government is apparently abandoning it by using a cynical trick to try to argue that it has taken the first step towards a double dissolution. The way in which this Prime Minister normally operates shows that the government is more interested in the next election than the welfare of the Aboriginal community of Australia. We are not prepared to be part of that cynicism. We are calling upon the government to show its colour and be prepared to debate its own legislation.

Therefore, we have moved this motion this afternoon and, hopefully, as a result of this motion, when we get to government business, the ATSIC bill will be the first bill called on. It should not take long before the final amendments that arose out of the Senate's own committee process can be dealt with and, therefore, the matter can be further progressed. When it goes back to the House of Representatives in the normal way, the government can then react upon it.

We know that the Prime Minister regards this place as an irrelevancy in what he regards as the legislative process, but that is not the attitude of the Australian people. The Australian people see that we have a responsibility to properly process government legislation, and we will meet that responsibility. We have done it in this bill. We have produced a better bill as a result of the amendments of this Senate, and we want that bill to be completed and go back to the other chamber to be dealt with in the normal course of events.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no notice of Senator Hill's motion. I do not know whether he gave it to anyone else but, if it is simply by way of ambush, that rather deflects from his point of accusing other people of playing politics over this issue. As I say, as far as I know, the government had no notice. It is, of course, a tradition of this chamber—
—Did you give us a copy of this new bill that you introduced today? No! Double standards; double standards always, isn't it?

—That is given at the first reading. I remind Senator Hill that even when the opposition was last in government—he has to stretch his memory, but he was here at the time although not many of those opposite were—it was one of the traditions of this chamber and the other chamber that the government orders its business according to standing order 65, which, I assume, is the standing order Senator Hill seeks to suspend at this stage, in the precedent it determines. At the moment, we have given a precedence of order, which includes the appropriation bills and others. Obviously Senator Hill, concerned about the possibility of going to a double dissolution, seeks to in some way pre-empt that by this move today.

PARA.TAB: As I say, it has been a tradition accorded to governments that they consider their legislation in the order in which they consider necessary to transact business. What he is seeking to do is hijack that out of the government's hands today by the suspension and what would be, if it was successful, a substantive motion to follow. We cannot ever support that particular process, no matter what his motives are, be they good or bad.

If Senator Hill does not like the order in which the business of the chamber is going, then of course he has the right to make those political points in that he thinks precedence should be given in the general political argument from one piece of legislation to another. But it is not a traditional right of oppositions to dictate to governments the order in which its legislation appears before chambers—not at all.

Senator Hill, in some of the substantive parts of his contribution, said that this was an urgent issue. It was not so urgent that it could not be sent off to a committee last year. Where was the urgency last year, with it being sent off to a committee? Therefore, the government will oppose this suspension.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the suspension but will speak to it only briefly. I think it is important that we respond to the points which have been made by Senator Ray.

PARA.TAB: This chamber was informed by the government by way of the Notice Paper and by way of a speech in this place by the minister responsible, the Leader of the Government, Senator Evans, on the last sitting day of the last sitting fortnight, that this legislation would be dealt with in the Senate expeditiously, that he would go away and look at the committee's report and consider the amendments recommended by the committee. So we came back to this place expecting to deal with this legislation yesterday. That is what the Notice Paper told us and that is what the minister had told us.

It was only because a journalist from the West Australian cared to read what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had said on Friday at a private little meeting at Hope Vale that we were given any clue that the government was prepared to use the cynical political ploy of introducing an identical piece of legislation—I emphasise, an identical piece of legislation—incorporating some of the less contentious amendments which had been recommended by the Senate select committee and passed by this Senate. After hearing late on Sunday night, Perth time, from that very astute journalist from the West Australian that the government intended to do that, I made some inquiries yesterday in an attempt to find out what the government was proposing to do and was told basically to `go hunt'—and that is the politest way of putting it.

We were astonished that the government was prepared to go down this track—absolutely astonished. The effect of what the government is proposing to do by bringing a new bill into the House of Representatives which is identical to the old one and which incorporates some of the amendments is of course for its own political purposes, ignoring the purposes, hopes and aspirations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians whom the bill seeks to serve.

In our wanting to ensure that the land fund bill receives the consideration of the Senate and then the consideration of the House of Representatives once the Senate passes the bill as amended, we have the normal process available to us; that is, that the Senate consider the modifications to the amendments that the Senate select committee has recommended—those amendments have been prepared and will be circulated subsequently, if this motion is passed—for there to be a third reading of this bill and for the government then to consider its approach to the amendments in due course in the House of Representatives when the bill leaves this place.

What the Prime Minister is proposing, by introducing a new bill in the House earlier today, creates an unnecessary delay in the processing of the land fund bill. As Senator Hill said earlier, it just means that the whole process starts over again: the bill comes back to the Senate; we go through the second reading stage again; we go through the committee stage again; and some time down the track we get back to the point where we are right now here in the Senate, and deal with the committee stage and the third reading once again—at which stage it will have to go back to the House of Representatives.

It is quite clear that the strategy put down by the Prime Minister has only one motivation; that is his own political motivation, a motivation which is entirely separated from the motivations, hopes and aspirations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The government has argued that the Senate, back in December, by referring the bill to a committee, failed to pass the legislation. It was interesting to note that Senator Gareth Evans, in his own contribution to the debate on the Senate select committee's report, commended the committee for the expeditious way in which it had handled its deliberations and for being able to report to the Senate within a couple of days of the ordered reporting date.

In other words, the committee proceeded expeditiously and fairly in consultation with Aboriginal people and reported back to the Senate. We fully expected to debate the legislation and were prepared to do so when the Senate sat yesterday afternoon. We are surprised at the political ploy of the government. Senator Ray talked about the forms of the Senate and traditions in this place. The government has thrown those traditions out the window. It has chosen to use a cheap political tactic for its own political advantage. Senator Hill is proposing to ensure that the traditional process of ordering the legislation through this place is adhered to. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Greens (WA) support the motion of suspension for the following reasons. It is extraordinary that the government is actually introducing another land fund bill in the House of Representatives today when the government's land fund bill is still before the Senate at the committee stage prior to its third reading vote. The only requirement to complete the Senate's consideration of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 is for the government to place the bill back on the Senate's program. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) considered it constitutional impertinence for the Senate to interfere with the House of Representatives program. Presumably, he will see it as equal impertinence to interfere with the Senate's program in the way that is currently being attempted by the government.

PARA.TAB: The reason for urgent suspension is that the Senate should be allowed to proceed with its committee stage consideration of the bill. The government is the only obstacle to the passage of the bill. It may well be embarrassed to continue the debate in the Senate, because the government may not want to pass the amendments and gain a bipartisan approach to its land fund. I believe that that is not in the national interest and that it is not necessarily in the interests of the Aboriginal people who seek that land fund. Alternatively, it may well be forced to eat its words regarding the opposition's stance on the land fund for Aboriginal people who are unlikely to gain any land via the Native Title Act. I think the government's tactic is disgraceful.

Senator Ray said that the government had been given no notice of this suspension and called it an ambush. I would like to know what Senator Ray calls the introduction of a repeat bill in the House of Representatives when the present bill is simply awaiting modified amendments that emerged as a result of the committee process. The government may be abandoning its consideration of this bill. It is not up to the government but the Senate to determine what it will consider. By his actions, the Prime Minister is not only indicating his well-noted contempt of the Senate and the parliamentary consideration of legislation; he is also indicating contempt for all the Aboriginal people who appeared before the committee, expressed their concerns about the unamended form of the bill and asked for some redress.

The purpose of moving to the committee stage of the debate today is to ensure that some of the concerns raised by Aboriginal people around Australia can be addressed by possibly modifying or putting new amendments. Those amendments would meet the concerns expressed by Aboriginal groups around the country and the government. To try to pre-empt that is, in my view, totally undemocratic and unworthy of a government that seems to be attempting to rule by the executive. I therefore support the motion for suspension. I have already indicated support for the proposition that the committee stage be proceeded with prior to the rest of the government business orders of the day at an appropriate time to give consideration to that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Campbell and to welcome the comments made by Senator Chamarette. I find it absolutely ironic that Senator Ray said we are hijacking the government's business when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is hijacking the business of the Senate. Senator Ray and the government have to recognise that, in the process of bringing another bill into the House of Representatives, they are hijacking the business of this place.

PARA.TAB: I put on the public record my congratulations to those people on the committee who collected further evidence. They are the proper processes that should have occurred in terms of this legislation. It should now come back into this place and be dealt with by the proper processes. It is because of the activity of the government that we have been forced to do what we have today. I know that other people want to comment on this matter, so I will finish. This is the proper process, in view of the fact that the government is abrogating its responsibility in bringing forward this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition and, it seems, the Greens have been engaged in nothing more than a time wasting exercise so far as this committee enterprise was concerned. That is evident from the way in which the committee report has come back to us, because the report of the committee involves recommendations that constitute no more than very minor changes to the terms of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill in the form in which it left this place and went off to be further considered by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Under those circumstances, it has been made perfectly clear that, if the committee stage were to now proceed and this original bill were to go to a third reading, the product would still be a bill that is manifestly unacceptable to the House of Representatives. Why it would be unacceptable has been made perfectly clear by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in introducing the second version of this bill in the House of Representatives today.

Putting it perfectly straightforwardly, the government's position is this: the Senate had ample opportunity to state its position, to consider its position, to debate its position. It did so at enormous length in the latter part of last year, and when it came to the point of passing the legislation in the Senate last year—after that enormously extended process—the Senate failed to do so. It failed to pass the legislation. It sent it back to the House of Representatives in a form that was manifestly unacceptable to the House of Representatives. That was made clear to the Senate. When the Senate was confronted with that result, the Senate failed to pass the legislation.

Under those circumstances the government has waited for a period of three months, as the constitution requires, has reintroduced the original bill with a number of the amendments that have been passed by the Senate—those amendments, in other words, which are acceptable, which do not offend the basic principles of the legislation and which do not make it unworkable—and has incorporated them accordingly.

The bill, after the expected process in the House of Representatives, will come to us for further consideration after next week. It will be an opportunity then to consider the matters of substance that people in the Senate seem to continue, understandably, to want to debate. So there will be an opportunity to do that. Senators will have an opportunity to put that on the record. We will have lost nothing in the process by following the government's preferred position on this, and that process will reflect the reality that the Senate has had its say on the bill and has failed to pass the bill in the form in which we want it.

The situation is that, if those opposite pass this particular motion now, as it appears they have the numbers to do, we will find ourselves dealing with the first bill, and so be it. We will deal with it in the committee stage. Those opposite have already foreshadowed what the results of that committee stage will be; namely, the passage of the bill on its third reading with some further amendments, one or two minor amendments, which do not do any particular further damage to the bill, although they might even marginally improve it, but which nonetheless do not go in any way to the substantive difficulties that we have and always have had with this legislation—fundamental difficulties of principle, fundamental difficulties that go to the unworkability of the legislation.

Those opposite are wasting time by going through this particular process because they are doing nothing more than working out a process that is preordained to produce yet another stalemate between the two houses. We and the government are trying to break that stalemate. We are trying to create a situation where a bill that is decent in principle and workable in practice is able eventually to be passed, notwithstanding the continued obstruction, small-mindedness and resistance of this particular Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obstruction? We're wanting to carry it.

—You want to carry the bill, yes, but a bill that is unworkable in practice; a bill that is wrong in principle in a whole variety of ways, as the Prime Minister spelt out, following the way in which we dealt with it in this place before; a bill that in the form in which the opposition is proposing to pass, and if it passes this motion now and finishes the committee stage, is not a bill that could ever be acceptable to the government or the majority in the House of Representatives. PARA.TAB: That is the environment in which we confront this. I have made the government's position clear. We cannot do anything about the vote. We will have to debate the legislation, accordingly, on the opposition's terms. But I make clear that the result of this whole process will be a complete waste of time.
