TALK.START.PARA: —I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to the Senate for allowing this matter of public importance. I am not going to talk much on the scientific evidence for the greenhouse related climate change. There have been several reports in the last few days. A cooperative effort by the CSIRO, Germany's Max Planck Institute and the US Office of Interdisciplinary Earth Studies said that, even if we succeeded in stabilising emissions at 1990 levels, greenhouse gases would continue to increase and would probably double by 2100. Another report by Dr Thompson, a mathematician from AT&T Bell, to be published in Science next month, confirms that greenhouse gases have a strong impact on climate change. Information confirming the relation between greenhouse gases and climate change and the mechanism and the severity of the impacts is readily available and convincing for anyone not wilfully blind.

PARA.TAB: We have already seen some of the sorts of impacts that are predicted under greenhouse related climate change. The drought not only had a devastating effect on the agricultural industry and rural community but also had a strong effect on the balance of trade and we went to importing food and feed. This is a major unstated cause of the bad current accounts figures recently released. While CSIRO has done some good work in climate modelling, virtually nothing has been done on the impacts of climate change. There are suggestions that we might lose our reefs and already scientists point to bleaching as a result of climate change. Algae are the major sinks of the planet, accounting for about half of the CO2 absorbed by plants each year. The algae are also being affected both by temperature changes and increasing ultraviolet rays due to ozone depletion. This will have massive impacts on oceans already under stress through overfishing.

Work done in the United States and Canada indicates that whole forests may die, along with the species that live in them. Other reports suggest that the gulf stream may disappear as a result of differential warming between equatorial and polar regions. The result would be a much colder northern Europe and the devastation of their economies. Basically, we have no idea what we are doing. The result is liable to be disastrous and by the time it is obvious it will be too late to do anything. Biological lag time means things will keep rapidly getting worse for 30 years before remedial action will begin to work.

I point out that there has never been a conference in Australia where people have brought together information on what is happening or could happen with individual species. We are talking about fish stocks, fish food stocks for birds and terrestrial species. In Australia, there has not been an occasion when scientific researchers and the various people working on that kind of information have come together to share that information. We are acting on a lack of information on species.

I congratulate the National Farmers Federation and support its call for action on retaining forests and promoting agroforestry. We need that and the Greens have already indicated their support for changes to taxation and other regimes that currently work for clearing and should work for preservation and land care. Sinks are not enough when your sources are growing logarithmically.

I would like people to remember this whenever a no regrets policy is mentioned. I agree with a no regrets policy. I have spoken about this on several occasions in this place. The very least the government should be doing is promoting a no regrets policy. But we think we had better broaden that definition very quickly. There is a lot to do if we really want to be in a position in 20 or 30 years time where our inaction is not intensely regretted by us and our children.

The Greens are not necessarily wedded to a carbon tax, although industry claims that no nation has one are wrong. Finland, Denmark, Sweden and Norway have carbon taxes as high as $US120 a tonne; that is, $A160 a tonne. But energy use can be reduced dramatically without such a tax as long as there is a political will and a decent integrated program. Is this possible? Absolutely.

California has almost double our population. Between 1980 and 1991 its population increased by 28 per cent, while its absolute electricity use went from 140 terawatts to 104, a decrease of 25 per cent and a decrease on a per capita basis of 41 per cent. Over the same period, the Australian population increased only 17 per cent, while our electricity use increased from 102 terawatts to 159. That is an increase of 55 per cent and a per capita increase of 33 per cent. The Californian economy was booming during that time. I seek leave to table statistics to back up those claims.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did California do it? It made a commitment to conserve energy. It regulated. It used economic incentives and disincentives. It used building codes and zoning. It assisted industry and householders to retrofit and to put in strong standards. Industry screamed but government ignored it. The result is a win-win situation where industry is thriving and people have reduced cost and increased comfort. The environment is much healthier. Sometimes it is worth seeing that, in these kinds of longer term areas, the concerns of industry do not necessarily relate to the real implications in the medium to long term. They are also far less threatened by international greenhouse measures. After all, they are already much of the way to the goals. We have done nothing, and every year that we do nothing the difficulty becomes greater along with the task.

PARA.TAB: I will not go into what California did or how, but I bring it up to show that there are models. It is possible. Anyone who is interested can look at what California has done, and I recommend that they do. It has been done and there is no reason why we should not do it too. But it will take some political backbone and at least the amount of forward vision possessed by the average five-year-old.

A lot of things can be done and they do not need to be too painful. A study by the former SECV found that energy efficiency programs had the potential to cut national electricity demand by 30 per cent, representing a saving of $3.6 billion in 1992-93 dollars. About half these savings could be achieved in residential and commercial buildings and in their fixed equipment for heating, cooling and lighting. An earlier report showed that such measures could create jobs and add significantly to state gross domestic product.

The study by the Goodman Group in 1992 called `Energy efficiency: opportunities for employment' shows that energy efficiency creates more jobs in the economy than fossil fuel power stations. It found that investing in energy efficiency creates 70 per cent more jobs per million dollars invested and that in the United States the $A4.3 billion spent per year on energy efficiency generated an increase of about 80,000 jobs. In other words, efficiency programs are good for the economy; they are not disasters.

Programs need to occur at all levels of government, although the federal government has a role to play. On a local level, towns and shires control building codes, zoning, town planning and the basic frameworks that determine what kinds of buildings will be available and how they are arranged. Good urban and town planning can reduce energy use in a number of ways. Building codes can include insulation requirements that not only reduce the need for energy but also, if applied across housing for all income levels, can markedly reduce the drain on low income families whose only alternative is often discomfort in poorly designed, flimsy homes.

Zoning can mean that infrastructure costs are lower, reducing rates. A combination of carefully controlled, mixed density housing, along with public park space integrating bicycle and walking routes, can mean that transport is cheaper, safer and more pleasant. Higher density does not need to translate into ant-heap style public housing blocks. It can also decrease pollution in the local environment. Urban design that brings shops and services closer to residential areas reduces much of the need for cars. A good public transport system coupled with higher density housing further reduces that need. Many of the most pleasant cities—San Francisco, Copenhagen and so on—are designed so that cars are rarely needed. They are a burden rather than a boon, yet businesses do well.

All this is local government and it brings extra benefits such as greater ease for recycling programs and better returns from them. Recycling will need to go beyond the warm and fuzzy stage of collection bins to look at the harder aspects of assuring that this results in a reduction of use of new resources. This means assuring that the actual resources are regionally recycled into high value products. It also means possibly looking at promoting reuse, reprocess products rather than recycling.

Federal government has a role to play in these areas. There are programs in the housing and regional development portfolio that could support this sort of thing, but there is little in the way of resources and general government commitment behind these programs, in spite of having some very good people on the ground. Little has been done to integrate energy conservation goals into such things as uniform building codes. If people are doubting my concerns, they need to look back to questions I have asked and had answered in the estimates process in regard to federal government housing and why there are no integrated energy or environmental codes built into those. The answer was, `Senator, this is about economic development and not about environment.' I cannot believe the lack of coordination there currently is in a number of programs in not bringing those win-win situations together.

State government also has a fundamental role in greenhouse reduction—as manager of state power utilities, public transport, main roads departments and so on. Obviously, laws restricting the sale of co-generated power into the grids, policies to push the grid into areas where the power sales do not pay for line maintenance, and so on, will work against energy conservation. A lot of urban design has been controlled by state government rather than left to local or regional government. State housing, while funded by the federal government, has been implemented by the state with the result that it has virtually no environmental design and is sited so that poorer people increasingly find themselves pushed to the urban fringes where there is least access to services, clinics, child care, libraries, shops and public transport. The impact of state policies has often worked to undermine both federal and local initiatives.

Federal government cannot wash its hands of its role and responsibility. We currently have federal pressure through the Hilmer plan and other forms to privatise power companies in a way that is likely to lead to competition to underprice power rather than to develop programs to support conservation. We are likely to see a fragmented and unregulated power system rather than one that is responsible. Yet promotion of product standards; assistance to industry in production of energy efficient products, in retrofitting and in developing co-generation capacity; promotion of renewable sources of power; and promotion of industries based on reuse and reprocessing are truly in the federal sphere, as is protection of the general environment and integration of the national greenhouse responses.

Part of the problem seems to be this ridiculous argument we have again and again about the constitutional powers of state, federal and local governments, the latter of which seem to be left out of the equation. It is about time we had a proper debate in this country about a new constitution so that people can talk about what they want in terms of those roles and ecological sustainability as a right of every citizen in this country rather than having this ridiculous buck-passing that seems to happen. It should be the responsibility of all tiers of government—not no tiers of government.

In short, there are many opportunities to substantially reduce energy use. I hope the government has the guts and the understanding to take them up and follow through on them better than it has done in the case of the energy card and other programs. I am afraid that, instead, it will let programs like better cities die without replacement. We would prefer a commitment to replace it with a program to integrate government energy objectives at all levels of government and in all programs—to go from demonstration to practice. The government will be deciding the future of Australia and its greenhouse policy. This can be done in a way that is cost effective and that enables people on lower incomes to have a better standard of living. It can be done in a way that looks to the future rather than just the profits of a few. We will be watching.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth government certainly does acknowledge the potentially significant impact of climate change resulting from the greenhouse effect and the impact that will have on the environment in this country and globally, and the impact it will have on Australia's economy. We recognise—and I think it is important to do so—the impacts of climate change on the global community and the global environment. We accept the need for Australia to participate in the development and implementation of an effective and integrated national and international response to meet the challenge of climate change. That is why the Commonwealth, state and territory governments have set out an integrated package of measures to respond to climate change.

PARA.TAB: In the national greenhouse response strategy we have adopted an interim planning target which effectively acts as a yardstick against which the implementation of our greenhouse response can be assessed. It provides a focus for action in Australia and establishes a context in which future planning can be undertaken.

Australia has a phased response in its approach to the greenhouse issue. The first phase was the NGRS, which was adopted in December 1992 by all state and territory governments. The national greenhouse response strategy concentrated on so-called no regrets response measures—that is, emission reduction measures that have net benefits or, at least, no net cost. These initial measures included a number of insurance measures to reduce uncertainty about climate change impacts. The insurance measures have included studies and research for which the government has provided $6 million each year.

In line with the involvement of all the stakeholders, we have established the national greenhouse advisory panel. This has involved key stakeholder groups, including the Business Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Conservation Foundation, Greenpeace, the Institute of Engineers, the Energy Supply Association of Australia, the Australian Gas Association, the Australian Consumers Association and the ACTU.

We identified the need to concentrate our attention on energy production, distribution and use because of the contributions to emissions from the energy sector. We placed an emphasis on an integrated least-cost approach to energy planning and on the importance of energy pricing better reflecting economic, social and environmental costs. We undertook to promote greater use of co-generation schemes in energy supply.

We identified the importance of minimum energy performance standards for appliances and equipment in the household, industrial and commercial sectors. The way is clear for the introduction of national minimum energy performance standards for appliances now that the Victorian government's concerns have been addressed. We also identified the importance of fuel efficiency and improvement in new motor vehicles. So I do believe that the government's approach has been a genuinely integrated one and a responsible one.

An important part of the Commonwealth's response to the greenhouse issue has been to involve all levels of government, and I believe that is an absolute necessity if we are going to have an effective and integrated response to greenhouse. There really is no other alternative available if we are to have a comprehensive approach.

The national greenhouse response strategy was agreed to by all state and territory governments, and it was also agreed to by the Australian Local Government Association. The national greenhouse response strategy sets out a number of measures that are already under way, particularly in the energy sector, to progress our response to greenhouse. The Commonwealth government has placed a special emphasis on the reform of the national electricity grid and on the introduction of a competitive market in the energy sector. The important challenge is to ensure that the economic objectives of the reform process and the environmental objectives of meeting greenhouse gas targets are integrated and pursued.

A number of initiatives are under way at state level which reflect the national reform agenda. New South Wales and Victoria are developing internal markets for electricity by separating generation, transmission and distribution and by introducing competitive sourcing of both existing and new sources of supply. Western Australia is considering options to introduce greater competition into its energy market, and today we heard news that the WA government in fact announced the construction of a new co-generation power plant at Kwinana which will use natural gas and result in something like 60 per cent less emissions than would the case with a coal-fired plant.

I think it is fair to say that we have taken steps to precisely measure and assess what are the sources of our greenhouse gas emissions in Australia and the impact on particular sectors. That information has provided the basis for the government to determine its further greenhouse response, and we have done that through Australia's greenhouse gas inventory which I was able to release in September of last year. The greenhouse gas inventory forms part of Australia's national communication which is required under the framework convention on climate change. The inventory is very comprehensive. It covers the full range of greenhouse gases. It covers emissions from all sources, large and small, from power stations to lawn-mowers and from aviation to off-road vehicles.

The inventory was very important in identifying the need for Australia to develop an additional set of response measures. The inventory identified emissions in the energy sector—about half of our total emissions—as making the largest contribution to Australia's total greenhouse gas emissions. It also identified that Australia's emissions are projected to grow by 82 megatons between 1990 and the year 2000. Of those, 66 million tonnes are expected to result from a growth in emissions in the energy sector. That sector obviously warrants significant attention in our efforts to reduce emissions in the future.

I think the inventory has provided a very useful tool with which we can develop an appropriate set of response measures. The government will be giving due consideration to the information made available through the inventory in determining the nature of its enhanced greenhouse response. Industry has recognised the scope for additional measures in the energy sector and there is certainly considerable scope for new measures to result in significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in that sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition was happy to support the Greens' matter of public importance so as to bring on this debate. We are happy to stand with them. PARA.TAB: This is an important subject and that is why, in the absence of the support of the minor parties, we were prepared to support the debate on this issue. It is quite obvious that members of the Labor Party were not interested in debating the subject either. Although they talk a lot—and Senator Faulkner has just given a demonstration of that; all the nice words but very little action and a hell of a lot of hypocrisy in the way the Labor Party has approached greenhouse—they are all over the shop. In the coalition, we are quite clear as to where we stand. Data from the UN shows that carbon dioxide will increase by 16 per cent in Australia between 1990 and the year 2000. At the Rio conference Australia agreed to freeze greenhouse emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. Gases such as carbon dioxide and methane trap heat and cause global warming, hence the greenhouse effect.

Cabinet is meeting today to decide Australia's position at the UN meeting on climate change convention signatories in Berlin next month. I did not hear Senator Faulkner indicate how his urgings were going in cabinet, but I suspect they were not going terribly well.What I do hope is that Senator Faulkner and our part-time Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who seem to be going to attend that meeting take the Australian public and this parliament into their confidence before they go making announcements in Berlin. It would be very nice for the part-time Prime Minister to make an announcement and indicate the strategy Australia will take before he makes an announcement in Berlin without consulting the Australian people.

It would be interesting to see the Australian contingent in Berlin. Senator Faulkner has completely lost the confidence of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has recently dismissed Senator Faulkner as far as the environment and the forest policy is concerned and put Senator Collins in charge of that. Obviously relations are not very good amongst our contingent overseas.

It is necessary to keep this whole question in perspective. Whilst we are said to be the fourth largest per capita emitter of greenhouse gases in the world, we are fairly small fry in the overall world event. Australia is responsible for less than 1.6 per cent of the total global warming gases. We really have to realise that there are more urgent things to do in the rest of the world than perhaps in our own country. There are a lot of proposals around for a worldwide reduction in greenhouse gas emissions—tradeable permits are spoken about and there are many other proposals. Those should be investigated and supported by Australia where appropriate.

We should also look very closely at this penchant we have for stopping any form of logging in Australia. This will simply mean that countries which do not have the same sorts of very scientific logging and forest policies as ours and which just slash and burn their forests will have a huge increase in the amount of wood and pulp that they will ship to Australia and elsewhere if Australia stops its forest industry, as is proposed by some of the minor parties. We really have to understand the effect of that when we look at what we do in Australia.
We do have to assist with research into and development of alternative forms of energy. In our policy at the last election, the coalition said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition will target a part of its R&D funding at environmental aspects of energy, production, distribution and use that have an international perspective . . .

So we are committed to looking at other forms—things like research into and development of solar and wind power, hydro power and perhaps even uranium. I would be interested to hear from the Greens whether they consider uranium power to be an emitter of greenhouse gas and, if not, why we do not look into that and get a bit more support for that in our nation.

PARA.TAB: I am often amazed that hydro power is one of the cleanest form of power going, yet again we have green, environmental and conservation groups and the very left wing of the Labor Party, the Democrats, stopping major hydro electricity projects that would do away with a lot of the greenhouse gas emissions. That is something I always find very difficult to understand.

As well, we really have to look at better, more efficient, transport systems, so that Australia still can progress economically but without perhaps the great emissions of greenhouse gases that we presently have. We have to look at things like the Darwin-Alice railway that will enable goods and people to travel in an efficient way. I am reminded that the Labor Party in South Australia spent $850 million on the Myer-Remin building—one building in Adelaide valued at $850 million. For the cost of that, it could have built the Darwin to Alice railway. The Labor Party really showed where its priorities lay.

Time is at a premium in this debate, but I do just wish to refer at some length to Mr Ian McLachlan's document entitled `Degradation in Australia: a clean Australia'. He quite clearly indicates that the underlying policy objective must be to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in an economically viable manner.The carbon tax which the Labor Party was proposing would, at best, reduce our greenhouse gases by seven million tones over the next five years. However, if we use the methodology of the national greenhouse gas inventory and revegetate 2,000 hectares of native forests and 50,000 hectares of plantation forests in each year, we can absorb approximately three million tonnes of greenhouse gases each year or 15 million tonnes over the five years at a fraction of the cost of a carbon tax and approximately twice as effectively in the absorption of greenhouse gases.

Mr McLachlan, in his very well studied paper which I had intended to quote from more widely if I had had time, has a plan for revegetation of Australia. It is not simply enough to stop clearing land, although this is a fundamental step in the restoration of land quality in this country. Having put an end to excessive land clearing, we have to implement a genuine and effective revegetation program. That is set out in Mr McLachlan's document. We support it in the coalition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the time that humans have been on earth, there have been considerable local impacts in many areas. We have now got to a situation in which the impact of homo sapiens on the global environment is such that it is impacting everywhere and in a very severe way. In relation to the composition of the atmosphere, because of our burning of fossil fuel and a number of other activities, we are changing the composition of the atmosphere everywhere around the globe faster than at any time during the whole geological period of the existence of the earth.

PARA.TAB: The importance of this lies, I think, in two factors. Firstly, although we have been looking out into space for at least 20 to 25 years to see whether there is other life out there with which we can make contact, we have failed to find any. It would seem as though this little rock in our corner of the universe is the only place that is capable of supporting life. If Einstein's theory of relativity is anywhere near correct, then it remains the only place in which our form of life will ever exist.

Yet—this is the second point—we are carrying out an experiment on life on this planet the results of which we cannot predict. Nobody knows precisely what effect changing the composition of the atmosphere so rapidly, and changing it to such a different composition, will have. The best scientific advice is that it will indeed lead to global warming, that there will be significant increases in temperatures overall, that there will be significant changes in climate as a consequence, that there will be significant changes in rainfall, that there will be significant changes in sea level and that there will be, therefore, very significant changes in the ability of the natural environment to maintain itself, particularly in national parks and areas that have been set aside to preserve existing wildlife, and also a very significant impact on agriculture around the world.

That we cannot predict exactly what those consequences will be I think raises very much two other principles. The first is the precautionary principle, which says that if you do not know what the consequences of an action are going to be then you are prudent if you proceed as slowly and as cautiously as possible. As this is a global experiment we are carrying out, we should, as a species around the globe everywhere, be cautious in relation to further increases in carbon dioxide, methane and other greenhouse gases.

It also raises a very significant moral question; that is, the question of intergenerational equity. Is it appropriate that we as the current generation should burn fossil fuel, cut down forests, increase the release of methane from coalmining and a number of other activities, increase the concentration of nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere, again for a whole range of human activities, and leave to our children and later generations the problems of solving those consequences when we do not even know what those consequences might be?

In the face of all this, I think the response of governments in Australia—federal, state and local—to this overwhelming problem has been totally inadequate. In fact, a paper which appeared just last week, Australia's greenhouse strategy—Can the future be rescued, by Dr George Wilkenfeld, Dr Clive Hamilton and Dr Hugh Sadler, states that the national greenhouse response strategy has not resulted in a single tonne of greenhouse gas reduction, that most of the measures to which the government points are measures which would have been taken for economic reasons anyway and that there has been not a single specific measure taken with respect to greenhouse.

Senator Margetts also said earlier that there had not been a greenhouse conference in Australia. I tell her that in 1988 the Democrats in South Australia ran a greenhouse conference with a number of very eminent speakers and on 15 March in Adelaide at the same venue, at the Institute of Engineers in Adelaide, we will be running another conference. I invite senators, if they want to hear about what can and should be done, to come to that conference. We have, among others, Dr Graham Pearman from the CSIRO, Dr Peter Newman from Murdoch University in Western Australian, Dr David Mills from the University of Sydney, Dr Mark Diesendorf from the Australian National University and Dr Clive Hamilton, whom I have just mentioned, from the Australia Institute.

I think it is terribly important, particularly in view of the imminent international meeting in Germany next month, that we really do start putting our house in order. That is why I strongly support the motion of Senator Margetts in relation to the urgent need for a strategy to tackle the problem of greenhouse.

As I said earlier, nothing has been done in Australia. We have seen the development of a strategy and we have seen some information made available, but nothing in terms of the actual attack on the problem has occurred in Australia at all. The defect in this lies not only in the environmental consequences, not only in the fact that we are now committed to at least a doubling of carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere and increases in the other greenhouse gases as well, because there is an enormous momentum in this whole process and therefore our children will have to adapt to some sort of change, a change that we cannot predict, but we are at the same time also denying ourselves the opportunity to advance so many of those technologies, technologies which in some cases we have a leading edge on in this country.

I mentioned Dr David Mills earlier. Dr David Mills from the University of Sydney has developed specific absorbative surfaces which in many instances make solar thermal derived electricity cheaper than that which comes from coal. Senator Margetts pointed out yesterday or the day before that the electricity grid in New South Wales has been pushed into remote areas to supply coal based electricity when in fact stand-alone solar thermal devices would be cheaper. So there are economic benefits there which the New South Wales government has denied to the people of Australia, by denying the opportunity to support this technology, to make it even cheaper so that we can then export that technology to other parts of the world.

That, of course, comes back very much to the feet of the federal government, which is blindly pursuing this Hilmer report, the idea of dividing up to electricity utilities, without at the same time giving primary consideration to the need for energy efficiency. I do not see, necessarily, anything inconsistent between the two, although I would prefer the state utilities to be left as they are and then to have imposed on them energy efficiency, and I would prefer the least cost provision of energy services rather than the provision of electricity. I think that is the pattern that has been followed in the States. However, if the government wants to go down that road it could still impose on those utilities, those end-use suppliers, that they supply not only electricity but also the end-use services which electricity makes available.

In the area of domestic solar hot water, only six per cent of houses in Australia have domestic solar hot water services on them. It is far more economical, far more greenhouse friendly and far more creative of employment and industry in Australia to go down the route of providing hot water for people—that is what they want—rather than providing electricity through which they then get that hot water.

There are many other examples like that. The government has put aside money for the ethanol research program, ethanol from cellulose. As I pointed out in a notice of motion yesterday, not one dollar of that money set aside in the 1993 budget has actually gone into that research. I pointed out in the last week we were here in relation to the $10 million that the government set aside for a solar hot water scheme that not one single domestic hot water system has been put aside as a result.

These things indicate a lack of commitment on the part of government. That is why this motion is terribly important. I hope the government in its cabinet meeting tonight will really get on with the business of not only talking about a plan but actually doing something because that is what is important and the matter is urgent.

SPEECH.PARA: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994
The purpose of the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 is to make amendments to legislation under the portfolio and to repeal obsolete legislation.

The bill makes amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to add one member to the Authority to represent the interests of Aboriginal people living adjacent to the Park. While research indicates that no Aboriginal people live in the Marine Park, there are thirteen Aboriginal communities located mainly along the northern part of the coast with an estimated population of 6,500 in addition to those residing in towns along the coast. Hunting, fishing and gathering of marine animals for subsistence purposes are major activities in inshore waters adjacent to Aboriginal communities and areas (including towns) where Aboriginal people reside. In the light of the Mabo decision and subsequent legislation dealing with native title, the special provision for this representation on the Authority of aboriginal interests is warranted.

The bill also makes provision for doubling most of the penalties provided under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, the incorporation of a mental fault element in accordance with the Commonwealth's criminal law policy and a change from indictable offences to summary offences for many of the provisions.

Penalties under that act have not been considered generally by the Parliament since 1988. Significant increases in use, demand and competition for resources have occurred since that time. Illegal activities in the Marine Park not only may reap substantial commercial benefits for the participants but also give rise to enormous and possibly irreversible impacts on the Marine Park.

Given the World Heritage status of the Great Barrier Reef, it is important that Parliament sends a clear message to potential offenders and the courts indicating that it views such environmental offences as very serious. The waste discharge penalties for the owners and controllers of facilities within the Marine Park have been increased from 500 penalty units to 2000. This is in line with other marine pollution legislation which attempts, through the imposition of high penalties, to deter persons from committing offences that might lead to serious impacts, such as those that arose in the case of the Exxon Valdez.

The bill makes provision for the preparation of statutory management plans for parts of the Marine Park and species and ecological communities within the Marine Park where such management plans are necessary. Given the dramatic increase in use of the Marine Park in the last ten years, it has now become obvious that the existing permits system is a poor tool for planning purposes, although it will continue to remain an excellent tool for general management purposes. Statutory management plans are therefore necessary to bridge the gap between zoning plans and individual permit decisions.

The bill increases the powers of Marine Park inspectors to improve the safety and efficiency of enforcement within the Park. The Marine Park covers an area greater than Victoria and Tasmania combined, and is the largest marine protected area in the World. It is most important that the inspectors have adequate powers to enforce the Marine Park Act in areas which may be quite remote. Much of the Park is not covered by mobile phone access and only a small area is covered by good quality seaphone.

The proposed amendments give inspectors the power to give reasonable directions to persons within the Marine Park for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the act. It also brings the provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act relating to arrest and search of arrested persons in line with the Commonwealth policy on the exercise of those powers. Changes are also proposed to the regulation making powers to allow for infringement notices to be given for minor offences in the regulations and to remove gender specific language from the Great Barrier Marine Park Act.

The bill makes minor amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to allow fees, collected under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 for permits, authorities and applications, to be paid into the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund. This implements a recommendation that such fees be retained by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service made in the 1992 Review of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.

The amendment also clarifies and groups together monies that can be paid directly into the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund and monies that must first be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund for appropriation to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund.

Amendments are made to establishing legislation which allows four statutory authorities under the portfolio, namely the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Sports Commission, the Australian Sports Drug Agency and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service the use of credit cards. This is to facilitate administration ease in day-to-day operations so that a good or service may be acquired by the agency using a credit card.
At the request of the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly, minor amendments have been made in the bill to the Norfolk Island Act 1979 to change the titles of the presiding officers in the Assembly.

The Australian Sports Commission Act 1985 currently provides for a board comprising a Chairperson, a Deputy Chairperson and up to ten other members. It has always been the Government's intention that these positions be filled by people with experience or expertise in sport—either as participants or as administrators.

Recent changes to Departmental administrative arrangements will see the Australian Sports Commission taking responsibility for additional sports related activities such as grants to life saving organisations. With reduced involvement of the Department in sport issues and to ensure that adequate links are in place between the Department and the Australian Sports Commission, it is proposed to have the Departmental Secretary hold an ex-officio position on the Commission's board. The proposed amendment to the act will enable that arrangement to be implemented without disrupting the operation of the existing board.

The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact, though some increase in revenue could result from the increased penalties for breaches of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975.

HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT BILL 1994
This bill proposes to amend the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973.
The amendments will give effect to the government's package of reforms to private health insurance. These reforms focus on consumer rights and provide:
.Value for money in private health insurance;
.A wider choice of products achieved by enabling health funds to make contracts with hospitals and doctors; and
.The reforms also provide for efficiency measures and equitable access.

Medicare is the centre piece of the government's health policy and enjoys strong community support. The latest market survey shows that over 87 per cent of the population support the Medicare program. Medicare provides an accessible, high quality public health system for all Australians.

Private health insurance offers a choice for those who want it, but it needs to be seen for what it is—a supplement to the public health system. However, those persons who choose this product are entitled to high quality and good value in the same way as buyers of any other product.

Mr President, I think it's fair to say consumers aren't getting that now and that is why participation rates for private health insurance are continuing to decline, with consumers suffering ever-increasing premiums and high and unanticipated costs when they use the private system.

The reforms will place the health insurance industry in a position to achieve efficiency gains and pass on the benefit of those gains to their members in the form of lower premiums and better controlled costs.
Mr President, I will now outline the main elements of the reform package.
Health funds have traditionally been seen simply as `bill payers'. These reforms will encourage them to be purchasers of health services and representatives of their members.
Under the arrangements proposed by this bill, from 1 April 1995, funds may enter into hospital purchaser-provider agreements with hospitals.
The primary aims of requiring contracts between funds and hospitals are:
to generate competition between health funds and hospitals, resulting in improved efficiency leading to better value-for-money, quality and access for patients;
to link hospital funding to appropriate quality assurance and accreditation procedures; and
to reduce restrictions on products offered, thereby allowing funds to operate according to market demand for different products.

The bill also attaches conditions to any such contract with hospitals requiring them to submit a single account covering all service and facility components and provide data for modelling, evaluation and research purposes.

In the first instance, contracts between funds and hospitals can be on the current basis of per diem payments, including the structure of basic and supplementary tables or on a casemix payment basis. The current basic table of insurance will continue to be available up to 1 July 1997 to hospitals which enter into a contract. On 1 July 1997, the basic and supplementary tables will cease and contracts will be structured on the basis of a casemix payment system.

There is a national commitment to replace the current private health insurance per diem payment system with casemix payments. Casemix is the most significant commonwealth health financing initiative developed in australia. It sometimes sounds arcane and technical—but basically it is a simple idea which enables the measurement of what happens in hospitals i.e. The episodes of care.

The term `casemix' means the types or mix of patients which a hospital treats, but can refer to any scientific approach to the classification of patient care episodes and ideas on how to use those classifications to help make decisions about health care.

The implementation of casemix payments will improve efficiency within hospitals and improve the quality and quantity of the information available on what takes place in hospitals, and hence improve quality and outcome of health care.

The commonwealth developed system—Australian national diagnosis related groups—would normally be used for acute in-hospital care under casemix payments. Other payment mechanisms—for example, per diem payments—would need to continue for longer term/non-acute patients, such as chronic psychiatric patients and nursing home type patients, until more precise episodic classification becomes viable.

Where hospitals and funds do not enter a contract arrangement, there will be a transition period during which the fund would be required to provide a benefit payment at a level determined by the fund. This will be an incentive for hospitals to enter into contracts, while providing protection for patients.

Mr President, there have been suggestions that these provisions give too much power to the funds and that they may misuse this power in an anti-competitive way, say to advantage hospitals that they may own. The government is satisfied that the trade practices act provides protection against anti-competitive action by any funds—and, in any case, the number of health fund owned hospitals, only about 6 per cent of private hospital beds, makes such anti-competitive action unlikely to be attractive.

Funds will be encouraged to contract with high quality, cost efficient hospitals. A fund with a large market share may be able to negotiate a lower price, and this is what competition is all about. However, the exercise of their market power must be consistent with the trade practices act which prohibits the use of such power to reduce competition.

The result of the introduction of this new approach is that consumers will be able to choose packages with lower premiums if they are happy to use the hospitals and doctors contracted by their fund. They will also be able to choose packages that cover them for the total cost of hospital treatment, eliminating the gap that often exists at the moment between the amount of the bill and the level of their benefits.
While it is likely that most funds will cover most hospitals, there will be a range of products that vary according to the range of services and number of hospitals covered.
For example, a product might cover all hospitals, or most of the major public and private hospitals, or a few small private hospitals according to the level of access consumers wish to have.

In addition, consumers could choose between full coverage, an agreed level of co-payment for lower premiums or products with known out-of-pocket payments similar to the current front end deductible arrangements.

Consumers will be able to purchase a product that best suits their need, at a price that best suits their budget. There will be more choice—not less—and for the first time, consumers will have information and power to exercise those choices.

Funds and hospitals will implement arrangements to avoid insured consumers unknowingly being admitted to hospitals not specifically covered by their health insurance product, and doctors will also need to play a role in referring patients to hospitals covered by the patient's health insurance product. However, for cases such as emergency admissions to non-contracted hospitals, funds will be obliged to make a payment based on average payments to contracted hospitals.

The bill requires health funds to offer a product which covers the full range of treatments and services in hospitals. Mr President, this will ensure that people with high health needs have access to appropriate private insurance.

The second part of paragraph 29 of schedule 1 to the bill will enable funds and doctors to enter into contracts for the provision of medical services rendered in hospital. The contract may exclude out-of-pocket costs or allow for a predetermined amount to be borne by the patient.

Mr President, this reform addresses one of the greatest concerns of private health fund members. Unlike the current arrangements, patients will know in advance of admission to hospital what medical expenses, if any, they will have to meet.

Mr President, contracted doctors will not be permitted to raise bills outside of the contract but these contracts will not be compulsory and contract payments may be made on whatever basis funds and doctors choose. For example, a percentage of the MBS fee, a retainer or some other agreed payment. Members may purchase this type of coverage for contracted doctors on an add on basis.

Clearly therefore, this is not introducing an American style managed care system. Doctors will still be able to receive fee for service and the structure of our private hospital system will not change.

Mr President, this legislation does not introduce `open-ended' gap insurance either. Although funds may negotiate whatever fees they wish with a doctor, if their contracts are too generous, higher premiums would result. Since higher premiums will lead to a decrease in market share, there is a strong incentive for funds to negotiate reasonable contract prices.

Paragraph 69 of schedule 1 of the bill provides for an amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973 to enable the 75 per cent Medicare benefit to be paid direct to the health fund for services rendered by contracted doctors.
In-hospital services rendered by doctors who do not enter into a contract with a fund will continue to attract overall payments equal to 100 per cent of the MBS fee.
Mr President, may I repeat, the focus of this legislation is on strengthening consumer rights and on making private health insurance better value for money.

The bill provides for the establishment of an independent complaints commissioner from 1 July 1995. The establishment of the commissioner will provide insured persons with access to an effective complaints handling mechanism which can investigate, conciliate and make recommendations in response to complaints about private health insurance products. A 008 telephone network will be put in place to provide insured persons with easy access to the commissioner no matter where they live.

One of the tasks of the commissioner will be to provide input to a private patient charter which will be designed to assist consumers in obtaining specific information from funds, doctors, hospitals, my department and the complaints unit itself. The charter will also encourage doctors to inform patients of an estimate of their fees and of the fees of other doctors involved in a prospective episode of treatment.
A separate bill, titled the Private Health Insurance Complaints Levy Bill 1994, provides for health funds to pay a levy to finance the administration expenses of the complaints commission.

Paragraph 70 of schedule 2 to the bill provides the Private Health Insurance Administration Council with the additional function of publishing information in relation to health funds' premiums, benefits and products to assist persons in making an informed choice about the product which best suits their needs.
Mr President, the final group of amendments are to improve the operation of some elements of the current environment.

Paragraphs 12 to 23 of schedule 2 of the bill remove the requirement for open membership organisations to conduct a separate health fund in each state. This measure will increase administrative efficiency and allow organisations to react quickly to changing circumstances. It will also reduce competitive differences between open and restricted membership organisations.

Section 67 of the National Health Act 1953 requires organisations conducting health insurance business to be registered under the act and operate in conformity with community rating. This provision was introduced from 1 September 1985 in response to the growth in health insurance by general insurers which, by imposing restrictions on certain benefits and on age, had the capacity to offer lower premiums and hence attract the young and healthy members away from registered insurers.

Subsequently, there has been an increase in the incidence of health plans being operated in respect of employee groups. These plans are not caught by the national health act because either no underwriting of the liability or premiums are involved or such plans are conducted under a discretionary trust deed arrangement.

The government remains committed to the principle of community rating. Paragraphs 9 to 11 of schedule 2 of the bill propose amendments to section 67 of the act which will require employers conducting such plans to register them under the act or cease to conduct the plans with effect from 1 July 1995. This will bring such plans into line with registered funds and, for example, require them to participate in the reinsurance arrangements.

The amendments would not prevent employers continuing to meet employees' premiums to a registered health fund. Paragraph 10 of schedule 2 of the bill contains a ministerial power to exempt certain schemes, for example where an employer meets health expenses not covered by employees who maintain appropriate registered health insurance cover.
Currently, funds are required to notify the secretary within 7 days after they change their rules, constitution or articles and such changes may be disallowed on a retrospective basis.

As a means to further safeguard community rating, paragraph 43 of schedule 1 of the bill provides for changes to be notified prospectively. Advice about changes in premiums will need to be provided 7 days before the day on which they are to apply while other changes to rules will need to be notified 60 days before the effective date. However, a ministerial discretion will be available to accept notifications for lesser period where the changes provide for the introduction of new products in response to consumer demands.

The opportunity has also been taken under paragraph 61 of schedule 1 of the bill to modify the pre-existing ailment rule to reduce administrative difficulties for funds. This change is not expected to have any significant impact on members.

Mr President, the decline in participation rates for private health insurance has attracted cries from the opposition parties, the AMA and industry groups for the government to subsidise the cost of private insurance by way of tax rebates. Persons on low incomes, such as pensioners, would gain no benefit from tax subsidies. Furthermore, such proposals ignore the fact that Medicare already provides funding for private patients. Any additional subsidy large enough to increase private insurance participation would cost more than treating the newly insured in the public system. Or, put another way, the massive budget cuts to public hospitals required to fund tax rebates, would have a far greater impact than any increase in demand from former fund members.

This bill, will place the health insurance industry in a position to work with hospitals, doctors and contributors to ensure the future of efficient and affordable private health insurance packages that offer both protection and value for money for consumers.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE COMPLAINTS LEVY BILL 1994

The bill provides for a levy to be imposed on health insurance businesses of registered health funds to finance the administration expenses of the complaints commission. It is proposed that the rate of the levy, which will be prescribed by regulations, will be a maximum of 25 cents per quarter for single contributors and 50 cents per quarter for family contributors.
The levy is not expected to exceed about 6 cents single and 12 cents family per quarter during the first year.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: We are more than happy to have the debate. Our concern is not that it suddenly be disposed of in one hit; our concern is that otherwise you were never going to bring it on. PARA.TAB: But to spring this on us now for no good reason, no explanation, when quite clearly you could have this debate continue tomorrow, suggests that you are just playing the same old games you have been playing ever since Senator Gareth Evans had the gall to suggest some months ago that there had been a failure to pass on the part of the Senate, when he well knew that the Senate was following its normal procedures by referring the matter to the committee and examining the detail of the bill as thoroughly as we did. —I find this issue absolutely amazing. I came here to speak on another issue, but I am compelled to speak on this one.
