SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 27 March 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits and disadvantages of the introduction of Hospital Purchaser-Provider Agreements and Medical Purchaser-Provider Agreements within the private health insurance system and, in particular, the impact of such a system on:

PARA.TAB: (a)the current ability of privately insured persons to choose their medical service providers;
(b)the quality of care provided to medical service users;
(c)the level of private health insurance coverage;
(d)the operation of the private hospital system and the medical profession, particularly in relation to the principles of the Trade Practices Act 1974; and
(e)the cost of private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I move this motion for a referral to the Community Affairs References Committee is that this legislation represents the most fundamental change since I graduated in medicine 38 years ago. It alters the system—in fact, it goes beyond that—because right from the development of modern medicine, which goes back 5,000 years, the basis of medical practice has been that a patient goes to a doctor and then the doctor becomes the patient's advocate and represents that patient in that history of illness.

PARA.TAB: What this legislation does is introduce contracts between doctors and insurance companies, so doctors no longer become the patients' advocate—they are contracted to insurance companies, and, to quote those memorable words on television, `there's even more'. The hospitals are contracted to insurance companies as well. But there is even more—some major insurance companies own the hospitals as well.

This is a very fundamental change in the whole structure of health care. For example, Senator Burns would not be able to come as a patient to me as a doctor. Normally, it would be my responsibility as the doctor to look after Senator Burns as the patient, but my responsibility would be to whatever health insurance fund he happened to be with, if he were with one, and not with the patient. I would be responsible to the insurance com

SPEECH.PARA: pany. I can draw an analogy with a house burning down, as happened to me once. My house burned down. I went to my insurance company and asked how much it would pay me for the episode. It said that it would give me a third of what I had the place insured for because it was 60 years old and under the system it had depreciated by one per cent per annum. It is no longer the responsibility of the doctor to look after the patient. It is the responsibility of the insurance company to look after people. I would not put my trust in an insurance company in those circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Let us go into what has occurred in relation to this legislation. It has been referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which is a one-day committee. We sought submissions. In fact, we have 67 submissions in all to date, and I have them with me. Who was consulted before this legislation was drawn up? Have one guess—the Australian Health Insurance Association. Were the private hospitals consulted? Not at all, even though they represent over 300 hospitals in this country. Were the public hospitals consulted, or the Australian Hospitals Association, which represents the rest of them, over 600 hundred hospitals? Not at all. The whole hospital industry was not consulted, and that is borne out by their submissions. Were the patients consulted? Like everything in health care, the last people who were considered were the patients.

In looking through this list of submissions I will read out what the submissions have said in relation to this: the National Community Advisory Group on Mental Health—against the legislation; a consumer,

Nicholas Tonti-Phillipini—against the legislation; the Council on the Ageing—against the legislation. In reading the 67 submissions, the only one I can find that is for the legislation is the Consumers Health Forum—a government front. Another consumer association, the Mental Health Advisory Group of the Northern Territory—against the legislation.

I have dealt with the hospitals. I have dealt with what submissions we have from the consumers. There are other consumers, of course, but they are not organised to that degree. What about the doctors? There is the Council of Procedural Specialists, the AMA, the Australian Association of Surgeons. None of them was consulted on the most fundamental change proposed in health care in this country in my lifetime. There was no consultation whatsoever. Do you think anybody outside this arena is aware of it? Are the patients and the individuals aware that this is going on? They do not have the faintest idea because there has been no debate. Is the media aware of it? They do not have a clue because it has to be spoon-fed to them to get them to understand it. They do not understand it.

Let us consider what is proposed. The proposal is that it go off to a one-day legislation committee. What chance do these 67 submissions have in one day? We are talking about extending the time of sitting today for a few hours so that we can consider the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill that has been introduced, but for fundamental changes to the health care system of this country you are proposing that it be done in a day so that it can be considered. The Australian Health Insurance Association, which originally represented all the private insurance associations, has split apart. The Medical Benefits Fund of Australia—which is the largest privately operated health fund in Australia, representing 1.4 million consumers, and I have its submission here—is against the legislation and has split from the AHIA. The Hospital Contribution Fund, which is also one the largest funds, has reservations.

The minister says that health insurance will be cheaper. It is not her intent to raise the numbers that are insured. She says that that is not her prerogative; it is against ALP policy to provide any sort of subsidy for health insurance. She says that it will make health insurance cheaper. On what basis does she say that? As I mentioned to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, the only advocate was Russell Schneider, who is the executive director of the Australian Health Insurance Association. In a speech he gave to an Australian Private Hospitals Association meeting in October-November last year, he said that it will slow the decline of health insurance but he will not guarantee that premiums will not rise. On what basis does the minister say that it will make health insurance cheaper? She has no basis because not in any of these 67 submissions is that said to occur.

You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Richardson—of some notoriety, perhaps—said that, in relation to health care, you had to have 40 per cent of the population privately insured to sustain the basis of the public hospitals, because if people need health care and they are not insured, they either self-insure or they go onto the public hospital waiting lists. He said that 40 per cent had to be privately insured. The latest figures show that it is as low as just over 34 per cent. It was 36.6 per cent at the last available figures. In our state of Queensland, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is down to 30 per cent. It is in free fall.

What do we get? We get this situation where this legislation is being introduced without consultation and without people even knowing. In estimates committee hearings last Thursday week I questioned the department and Senator Crowley, who was representing the minister. They did not know what the result of it was. It was a giant experiment—that is what we were led to believe—`We are going to try this experiment on the Australian public. We have no idea what the outcome is going to be.' If I could draw an analogy, what will occur in this situation with free fall is that it will be like closing all the private schools in Australia and sending those children to the public school system.

There is a crisis. Everybody acknowledges it. The front page of the Courier-Mail yesterday was devoted to the crisis in health care in Queensland. There is overcrowding of our public hospitals. There are waiting lists that are extending out. I have mentioned previously in this chamber that there are waiting lists that extend to four years in some specialties. I see in the latest report commissioned by the government into waiting lists that it is unable to tell us what the waiting lists in Queensland were. The minister for health there said that it was because they do not have the computer equipment or the structure in Queensland to even find out what the waiting lists are. So we still do not have a true estimate of what the waiting lists are in Queensland and in other states. But we do not have to; we just have to ask some of the people who are on those waiting lists.

At the Prince Charles Hospital in Queensland we have records of where people have died while they were on waiting lists there. That is documented. There is under-utilisation of the private hospitals. To a large degree all of this is due to the rapid ageing of the population and to the rapid increase and use of modern technology. This is reflected in the rapid increase in the utilisation of diagnostic facilities, particularly in relation to radiology and also in relation to pathology and the other modalities.

I will deal with the provisions in this motion one at a time. The first is to discuss the current ability of privately insured persons to choose their medical service providers. I have had correspondence with Mr Schneider on this very matter. At present there is unlimited choice. Any one of us can go to a general practitioner of our choice or, in turn, to a specialist of our choice without restraint. We may be constrained by our ability to pay for that particular medical service provider, but we always have the opportunity of going to a bulk-billing clinic in the case of a general practice or to a public hospital.

The changes in this legislation will limit choice. Whichever way you look at it, it will limit choice. The specialist in this case, in relation to a private hospital, will need to be contracted to that hospital and then, in turn, that specialist is contracted to the insurance company. So whichever way you look at it, you cannot say that there will be more choice. There will be a limitation of choice as it exists today.

The second point in the motion is in relation to the quality of care provided to medical service users. Does anybody really think that when the health system is controlled by the insurance companies the quality will improve and there will be a decrease in price? It defies logic. It defies all the experience that any of us have had in relation to any action regarding the consumption of materials. The quality will inevitably decline because it will be quicker and sicker through the hospital system, as the AMA said.

The third point relates to the level of private health insurance coverage. To an extent, I have done that already. The fourth point relates to the operation of the private hospital system and the medical profession, particularly in relation to the principles of the Trade Practices Act. That relates to the fact that, in effect, you are introducing a collusive bargaining process which will disadvantage an individual patient. The final point relates to the cost of private health insurance. Neither the Australian Health Insurance Association nor any of the other organisations—the Council of Procedural Specialists, the AMA, the AAS, the RACGP, all the providers—believe that it will get the cost of health insurance down.

If you are going to introduce something, you normally need a model. Where have preferred provider organisations been developed in the world? In the United States of America. I almost laugh at this because when I entered this chamber nearly five years ago Senator Tate was representing the minister for health in this chamber. One day I interjected across the chamber that the standard of health care in the USA was the best in the world, provided you could afford it. That was thrown back in my face time after time by Senator Loosley and by Senator Tate—mocking me for what I said about the standard of health care in the USA and saying that that was what the opposition was going to introduce into this country. We were not at all, as you well know. Never at any time was that suggested, but it was again part of that campaign of denigration, obfuscation and—dare I say it—

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—The prevarication that went on in the last federal election.
—That is not what I thought you were going to say.

—I knew that, Senator Sherry. It was that big three letter word beginning with `l' and ending with `e'. That was thrown across the chamber at me many times, and here we have, with this legislation, the introduction of the American health care system. Roll on the Stars and Stripes! That is what it is. Look forward, Australia, at what has happened in the big old US of A—rocketing health costs and collusive bargaining. I just read a book about it, as a matter of fact, and it was quite fascinating.

PARA.TAB: It is always interesting when governments try to control things; they always get it wrong. The ALP has had 12 years to tinker with the health system of this country. I ask those opposite to trot out anybody in Australia who will tell me that the health system has improved in the last 12 years, that there is better access, that people are being treated much more expeditiously, that the quality of care has improved. Three years ago I asked the secretary to the department where in his report the word `quality' was used. I can tell you it did not appear. It was fascinating that it appeared the following year, though. The word suddenly jumped out of the box and got into the report. But there we are. This legislation is designed to bring the American preferred provider system into this country.

It should be obvious to all that there needs to be considered debate on this legislation. If we are genuine in trying to improve and patch up the Medicare model—because we in the opposition believe that it should be continued, that there are many benefits produced by a universal health insurance system—surely it must be obvious to all of us that there needs to be more consideration than a quick legislation committee consideration. I do not believe that we are going to get anywhere unless we spend time with this. I know that Senator Lees and the Democrats believed that initially and I am not sure where they stand on this matter at the moment, but surely Senator Lees will agree with me that these 67 submissions—I am happy to go through them one at a time, but time probably constrains me—reveal almost universal condemnation of these measures.

I think it is important that we have these various people before the legislation committee. We have tried to condense the various representatives and group them together, but I do not believe that the object will be achieved if we try to condense them into a legislation committee meeting. I believe that this matter should be sent to the Community Affairs References Committee so that adequate consultation can occur about the very genuine submissions that we have received from over 67 different organisations and individuals. I commend the motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with two things Senator Herron said. Firstly, and most importantly, this is a fundamental change to the way the private health sector will operate in this country. The basic detail in this legislation is certainly controversial. It has attracted some 67 submissions. The second thing I would like to agree with is the comment about lack of consultation. It is not up to me to talk about why that occurred. I leave it to some later speakers from the other side to explain why there has been so little consultation. There was, I understand, a couple of, how shall we say, appointments kept, but discussion and consultation to me is a two-way process. It was not consultation. There may have been a meeting but there is no result shown in the legislation, no indication that people were actually listened to when they had those appointments.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Herron that these submissions are highly critical—bar one. However, what we are looking at now is a committee process from which will come a substantial number of amendments and even the department, although we will not get down to specific details until after the committee hearing, has agreed that amendments are certainly going to be needed in a large number of areas.

Something about which I cannot agree with Senator Herron is that we are simply introducing the American model. We are not, because we have Medicare backing up and underlying our health system here in this country. This legislation is about trying to put some sort of a ceiling over or floor under the private sector so that we can look at some cost containment. People are getting out of private health insurance, firstly, because the premiums are increasing and increasing and, secondly, because they are being left with bigger and bigger gap payments, many of which they knew absolutely nothing about before they went into hospital. I do not believe there is any excuse for elective procedures. Doctors should be obliged to inform patients of the full costs up front. I know many doctors are doing that but, unfortunately, it is still far too few.

For Senator Herron to suggest as he did in his speech that all the submissions are against the fundamental proposal is simply wrong. If you read through the submissions, you will see that they are clustered into different groups concerned about different parts of the legislation. The majority of submissions are from small hospitals, private hospitals, but not all; some of the public ones are also just as concerned about this. An amendment which most of them agreed would sort out a fundamental problem is the substantial default payment. In other words, if a particular hospital is not contracted with that insurance company, people insured with that company using that hospital will still be able to get a substantial part of their costs refunded. That is one of the amendments that the Democrats will be moving. The exact level of that default will depend on what we hear during the committee hearings on Friday and Monday.

I must add that, if we do not have sufficient time, then our committee can simply ask for an extension of time. There is nothing to prevent the legislative committee from asking for more time if we find that the witnesses on Friday or on Monday are not able to get through all their concerns. Indeed if the committee, having selected its witnesses based on the cluster of issues that each is concerned about, wants additional witnesses to talk about specific issues, it can arrange further hearings.

Senator Herron also made the comment that the media is not aware of the legislation. I would question that. I think there are certainly some journalists who are following this quite closely. Liz Jurman and Amanda Meade of the Sydney Morning Herald are just two of them. They understand the legislation. My concern as far as the media goes is the quite misleading advertisement by the procedural specialists. There are grains of truth and genuine concerns in the advertisement. However, the half a dozen letters I have received as a result of that ad are about the gap payments with which people have been faced in the past. Surely it is the procedural specialists themselves to whom these people should be talking about some of those problems.

Before I deal in detail with the motion before us, I would like to look at the legislation and some of the key issues raised in the submissions. I will go through some of the major ones. I have already mentioned the default payment which is probably the key issue for 60 or 70 per cent. It is mentioned in submissions from the AMA, the hospitals and the consumer groups.

One of the other major concerns is the possibility under this legislation for the insurance companies to opt out of psychiatric and rehabilitation services. They will find it more attractive to offer packages that do not have any psychiatric or rehab cover. Indeed, one insurance company is already doing that. Of particular concern is that this company is targeting young people and convincing them they do not need any psychiatric cover, because it can offer them much cheaper premiums. Looking at the statistics, we find that something like one in five of us are, at some time in our lives, going to need some support in the psychiatric health area and it is of great concern that this legislation could allow insurers to disadvantage people in this way.

We also need to note the fact that, despite comments by the government last year about full financial disclosure and aggregate billing, they are not covered in this bill to any great extent. These are among the other issues raised in a number of the submissions. Another is the question of privacy which comes up from two different angles. As far as the Trade Practices Act is concerned, it is the question of applicability to this legislation that is the cause for concern. That is why the committee has chosen to request that the trade practices people come before it and give their version of whether or not they will be interested in this legislation and whether they will be able to deal with the complaints resulting from it.

The start-up date has been contentious from the start and it is one issue that is certainly up for amendment. We will look at a far more reasonable time frame, particularly for the smaller hospitals, to enable them to come to grips with these particular changes. We need to look at patients' rights and also the ability of doctors to negotiate as groups rather than as individuals. They are some of the major concerns.

I believe that the legislation committee is capable of dealing with this legislation. This committee has dealt with quite a number of very complex pieces of legislation. It has been able to get through, before today, the committee process in a room upstairs and has been able to do it successfully. I suggest that Senator Herron's moving this motion today as opposed to after the committee has been through its processes, indicates that he is really saying that the committee is not capable of getting it right this time. Perhaps what we need to do is go through the debate in the committee stage.
Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —By implication you are saying that the legislative committee is not capable of handling it.
—No, not at all.
—If it is, then let us get on with it.
—It's the time frame.
—Let us look at the time frame. I believe with this legislative committee's workload it is possible to get through this in two days.
—It's the same people.

—If it is, then the legislative committee has a very similar membership and is quite capable of making the decision to extend the hearings further. Except for the fact that Senator Herron is the chair of one committee and Senator West is the chair of the other committee, I can see very little difference.

PARA.TAB: We should give the committee the chance to proceed. What we will come out with after the meetings on Friday and Monday and the discussions this week is quite a different piece of legislation. If we get to next Thursday and it is not possible for us to reach any sort of agreement and we are still looking at a piece of legislation that very few people support then we can revisit the whole issue of where we go from there.

I will now look at the motion before us. The first section deals with exactly what the submissions before us deal with—the hospital purchaser-provider arrangements and medical purchaser-provider arrangements within the private health insurance system. That is what I believe we will be able to deal with as we proceed through the legislative committee. We will be able to ask questions of the key witnesses. We have called witnesses from both sides of the fence—those who seem quite happy with the amendments and those, like the procedural specialists, who are going to remain implacably opposed to it no matter what we do.

The next part of the motion deals with the current ability of privately insured persons to choose their medical service providers. What we really should be doing if we want this as a term of reference at some later date is looking at the effect of the legislation as amended not as it is at the moment. I agree with Senator Herron that, as it is at the moment, there are some major questions. If we still have major concerns in the future that may be something we need to look at.

In relation to the quality of care provided to medical service users, I am sure we will find that Australia has amongst the best standards of care in the world. Perhaps we should be looking more at some of the questions raised about the possible changes after this legislation is passed. As for the level of health insurance, there are statistics on that which come out regularly. The Trade Practices Act questions can be dealt with when those people are before us on Monday. As for the cost of private health insurance, basically everyone is arguing that it is too high. That is something else that can be dealt with once we have seen the effect of this legislation.

If we put this question to the committee perhaps we should also put the question of looking at the costs of private health. Perhaps we should also look at specialist fees and charges, hospital charges and the increases in hospital fees. The private hospitals that I have visited in my home state in the last few weeks have told me that they have not had increases from the insurance companies to even keep up with inflation. There is very little room for us to find any cost blow-outs. There have to be reasons for this somewhere in the system. If we do need to look at this further down the track then I would certainly like to have the time to debate these terms of reference in more detail and look at extending them.

This is something that should be looked at in the future. Perhaps the most important thing to consider if we want a reference for this committee at the moment is a monitoring process for casemix. I would like to see that not just in the public sector but in the private sector as well. I would like to look at what is really happening. Are we right in saying that we are seeing, at least in two states, a reduction in care given to some sections within the community, including people with disabilities and older people? If we want a useful reference for this committee, I would ask that we pass this legislation and then set up a decent monitoring process, which I must say is in the AMA's submission. We should then look at monitoring casemix in both the public and the private sectors and not continue the constant buck passing between the states and the federal government that is occurring at the moment. They are simply putting it into black holes rather than using the money freed up by casemix to actually improve the health services in those states. I cannot see why we have to deal with this matter today. It is something that we can come back to a few months hence once the amended bill is through this place. TALK.START.PARA: —You shouldn't have been having a meeting while the Senate was sitting.

I think that is the most disgusting and despicable thing that has happened to a senator who has had the opportunity of chairing a committee in this place. You did not even have the decency to warn the committee or discuss with the committee that this was going to happen. Then we see the matter in here as business of the Senate. I find it so annoying and so disgusting that it nearly leaves me speechless except that it is such an important issue. We have heard a lot of diatribe tonight that the issue has been sprung on us and that there has been no consultation. Honestly, where have people been living for the last two years—under stones?

PARA.TAB: When former Senator Richardson was a minister, he raised the issue of the declining number of people taking out private health insurance. We then had a discussion paper that arose out of his concerns. That was released in December 1993, which is nearly 15 months ago. For anyone in the industry to have the gall to say that they did not know anything was happening is just beyond belief.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—We have had the criticism that there has been no discussion and no consultation. If people did not know it was on, then they must have been living somewhere else. We have also had the ACTU caucus working party group, which some opposition senators do not like very much. However, we do at least discuss things with groups. There has also been an IDC on the issue, but the opposition chooses not to take much notice of that.

PARA.TAB: As I said, this is an important issue. Medicare is something that the people in this country view as a very important cornerstone of their health care, and it is very good. People keep saying that with Medicare they know what it is going to cost them. They use their Medicare card and they are covered. But if they choose to go to a private hospital or to be treated as a private patient, they do not know what it is going to cost them. The bills, which are from people they have never seen and for services they did not even know they had to have or had been given, keep coming in. This is the critical complaint that I keep getting from people who have the top cover of health insurance. My next-door neighbour had a cataract operation. She was $6,000 out of pocket. These are the sorts of reasons why people are opting out of private health insurance.

This legislation will give those people who opt to have private health treatment a similar sort of safety net. They will know what it is going to cost. But I suppose there are people with vested interests out there who will not want the general public to know that they are charging 50 per cent or 150 per cent over and above the common schedule fee. That is probably the issue that is causing the most annoyance to and the most noise from organisations such as COPS, the Council of Procedural Specialists. We are hearing a lot of hip-pocket nerves squealing on its part because it does not want to have to justify to anybody how much it is charging its patients and why.

This bill is about making sure that people understand how much their private hospital cover, their private hospitalisation and their medical and allied services are going to cost them. That is the basis of this bill. It is about providing some cover and some safety net for people who choose to have their own health insurance.

We hear that people should take out private health insurance and have a choice. A lot of people have a choice, and they choose to self-insure. But nowhere from the opposition or the Democrats have I heard any comments about what they think about people who self-insure. It appears to me that the opposition does not think people should self-insure. A lot of people who have sufficient income can make that decision and that choice, but those opposite would not want them to do that.

We know that the number of people with private health insurance has dropped. It was very good of Senator Herron to provide us with the status of the number of people with private health insurance. But what he did not tell us was: has the occupancy rate in private hospitals decreased? Has the number of bed days decreased? I suggest that he read the submission from the Australian Health Insurance Association, which is headed by Mr Russell Schneider. The submission contains some very fascinating statistics which indicate that the level of use of private hospitals has not declined. It is very important that people be aware of the fact that people may be opting out of self-insurance but they are still opting to have private health services.

The other issue I wish to raise—I presume those opposite do not want to hear about this—relates to the complaints mechanism provided in this bill. People who have complaints and problems with their health insurance or their private treatment will have a mechanism by which they can voice their complaints. Their complaints can be resolved by an independent person. Isn't it strange that people would not want that? If you have private health insurance with Medibank Private and you have a complaint, you have the right to have that complaint heard by the ombudsman. Why shouldn't all of the other private health insurance funds be subject to the same criteria, the same assessment and the same regulation as Medibank Private? Medibank Private in its submission had no problems with this. I am very concerned about people who do not want to see the introduction of complaints mechanisms and who talk about caring for the consumer. Those opposite want to delay this bill and do everything they can to prevent it from being passed. They do not care whether the consumer has a complaints mechanism. These are the sorts of double standards with which we are being faced today. It is despicable that this is going on.

We also read in the submissions how important choice is and that you must have the right to the doctor of your choice and to be referred to the specialist of your choice. I would suggest that most people out there today who are referred to specialists would not have much of an idea as to whom they were being referred. The average person is not in a position to make a choice about whom they will be referred to. Mind you, because people in rural areas cannot get doctors to come out to them, they do not have any choice. They have to go and see that one because that one is probably the only one in the town. But that is another issue.

People who are referred by their general practitioner to other health professionals really do not know who they are being referred to. They may have some idea of the reputation of the person, but they have no idea of the person's professional capacity. They have to trust their GP. The GP chooses whom the patient is referred to, not the patient. It is held up as being sacrosanct that the patient must have their own choice of specialist. I would suggest to you that if the majority of people in this place, with the exception of half a dozen people here in this room, required referral to a medical speciality, they would not be able to choose whom they wanted because they would not be in a position to make that decision. Senator Patterson, Senator Herron and Senator Woods are in a position to choose, but the majority of people in this place do not have the same medical knowledge and paramedical knowledge that they do. Therefore, they are not in a position to make the same choice. The argument that people must have a choice, which keeps being trotted out, is the greatest load of rubbish. It is absolutely useless.

Another thing we kept hearing in those submissions that Senator Herron talked about was that some of the organisations want the collection of data to be done by an independent organisation. If it is done by an independent organisation, it then ceases to have the protection of the Commonwealth and therefore the protection of the Privacy Act. It would appear from some of the submissions that it would be a commercial venture. Wouldn't that be absolutely wonderful? It would mean that your name would be on another mailing list. Some of the drug companies that might be interested in flogging their new product might be able to ring up this independent organisation and purchase the mailing list of everybody who is being treated for a gastric ulcer or rheumatoid arthritis or something like that.

How much protection would you be giving people? You would not be giving them any because, firstly, it is a commercial venture and therefore the lists can be flogged—there is no other way to put it—and, secondly, it is not under the Commonwealth umbrella and therefore it is not under the Privacy Act. This legislation that we are about to bring in would be under the Privacy Act and therefore it would have the protection of the Privacy Commissioner. That is a very important point for people to be very conscious and aware of.

This is an issue that is of great importance. As I said earlier, I feel offended that the opposition should think that the legislation committee is not capable of dealing with it. We are capable of dealing with this. We are in fact in the throes of dealing with this. I am not sure, in terms of the standing orders—and this is probably something that the Clerk is going to have to ponder over—just where we go when we have this sort of stunt being pulled.

Next week we will put in a report of our committee's deliberations. What will happen? Will it come into here? Because there is a reference inquiry going on, will we be able to deal with it? Or does it mean that, as a government, we will come in here and have everybody else ganging up on us because they decide they want to stall for a bit more time? This is the sort of disgusting thing that undermines the good government of this country and the running of this House. I think that is something that people have to be very conscious of.

I thought this whole issue was one that we would be able to work out, discuss and negotiate. Certainly, I thought we would be made aware that amendments were being circulated. Whether we as the government liked them or not—maybe there were some that we would have to accept—is another matter. But in this situation, we were not even made aware of this. We are being ambushed at the pass.

I know that some opposition senators will follow me and say that I have done my usual doctor bash. So be it. As a nurse, I suppose that is something my profession gets into fairly regularly. I suppose it is a healthy inter-professional rivalry. They will also plead the case of the procedural specialists in the AMA. They will probably plead the case of some of the private hospitals, too. I think that is sectional interest, and it is not being concerned with what is good for the patient.

If you think that everybody should be able to afford private health insurance, I suggest you read the submission from the Council on the Aging. This very good submission points out the economic breakdown of people who should be encouraged into private health insurance. That is very important. But for the bulk of people, particularly the aged, Medicare is the best thing. If we do not address this issue—and it seems to me that the opposition's proposal is nothing more than just a stunt to prevaricate a bit longer—then we are going to undermine what we have got. We need to look only at the opposition's policy the last time it went to the polls. It was going to help low income people get health insurance. But it was still not prepared to deal with this issue of people finally being left with bills for services under health insurance.

Five or six items are listed for discussion. These all go to the nub of the bill. I do not think I can repeat enough that people should think carefully about the fact that two days for hearings have already been provided—Friday and Monday morning of next week. I hope we can finish by then, but the indications are that we will continue for longer. This is already being dealt with. I do not know why we need to deal with it again. It seems to me that it is defeating the whole purpose. It is adding to the workload of the committee.

The reporting date is 27 March. There is only one up week between now and 27 March. Do senators really think that they are going to spend that whole up week tramping around the countryside or having hearings with people who are concerned with this issue? What will happen to the work that the committee secretariat has already done? It is a separate section and a separate committee. Therefore, all of it will have to be duplicated if those submissions are going to go from one committee to the other. All of this sort of stuff has to be taken into consideration. I think this is typical of the absolute sham the opposition is starting to perpetuate in the way it is handling and treating committees. I am deadly opposed to what Senator Herron has moved.

Women make up over 50 per cent of our community and they are very important to everyone, whether they are in business or not. This report was prepared in response to a request in June 1993 from the Hon. Kim Beazley for the council to examine the issues surrounding small business, employment growth and skills formation. The report was formally forwarded to Minister Crean on 30 June 1994.

PARA.TAB: The report said that a number of strategies had been put in place to address the needs of young women and assist them with their career choices. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has developed a career kit to be used by young women that contains information about careers and the fields that are expected to grow or provide stable employment through the 1990s. The kit that it put together obviously would be of some help.

I make just a couple of remarks about what may be myths or things that people have thought over the years which probably are not always correct. One of the most common causes of business failure has been identified as poor business planning, lack of business plans or underdeveloped business plans and unclear goals. Research indicated that women in particular are less likely to have a formal business plan at start-up than men. This is basically surprising to me as it was, I think, to the research team, given that one of the reasons identified for women having a higher success rate than men in the start-up of businesses is their more thorough research of the business start-up, taking longer and drawing on wider sources of information.

Other areas, of course, can make it more difficult for women to start up in business. It is interesting to see here at the table today the minister who has a fair bit to do with child care. The council, in its deliberations, was made very much aware through the many submissions it received—in particular, on the supplementary work on women and small business—that one of the concerns in both establishing and operating a small business as an employee is child care and the other carer responsibilities. Unless they are properly and adequately provided, especially in country areas, it makes it very difficult for women to get into business.

Another part of the survey made the point about finance. Historically, the point had been made that access to finance had been an area of concern for women, and one that has been generally perceived to be one of the main barriers to be overcome by women in establishing and operating a small business. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Anecdotal evidence and research concerning women and their success in gaining access to finance however is contradictory and confusing.

A recent survey by the Yellow Pages Australia small business index found that there is no strong evidence that female small business proprietors are less successful in dealing with banks than are males and that women who applied for finance were, on average, more successful than their male counterparts. I think that is something that surely—if this research is correct, which I presume it is—has been put to rest. The report went on to say:

This finding contrasts with a belief by a sizeable proportion of the survey population . . . that banks and other financial institutions may treat women, in general, less sympathetically than they treat men.

I know that my wife, who is a partner with me in some businesses, can more than adequately hold her own with any bank manager, and I am sure that Senator Panizza's wife would be able to do the same. Women are generally very thorough in their approach to business, and the point was made that it is a myth that they are less likely to get finance. I am glad that myth has been put to rest in this report. I commend the report to the Senate.

In the Senate hearings on the Commonwealth Bank in June 1993, Mr Payne, the executive director, conceded that 300 to 350 people had been compulsorily retired in Victoria. The numbers, from information I have, have risen since then.

PARA.TAB: One former employee of the bank pointed out in the Sunday Age on 19 February this year that many of the voluntary redundancies were, in effect, voluntary in name only. Mr Tom Davey, a former manager, explained it in this manner:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bit like you are in a plane and the plane is going to crash and you are given the choice, you can jump out of the window right now and be killed or go down with the plane and be killed.

The job losses in Victoria were exacerbated by a decision by the Commonwealth Bank to strip all head office activities out of Melbourne. Many Victorians believe that the bank is simply out of touch. Business complains that there is a lack of knowledge, particularly where Melbourne property is involved. Customers are deserting the banks in droves. According to Barbara Biggs in the Sunday Herald-Sun on 12 February, CBA staff are being verbally and physically abused by irate customers after massive staff reductions. The unions are also fed up with the attitude of the Commonwealth Bank. Mr Steve McKenna, the State Secretary of the Finance Sector Union, has been quoted as saying:
The way the Commonwealth has treated people in Victoria, both customers and staff, is appalling.

He also said that the Sydney based management of the Commonwealth Bank did not seem to care what happened in Victoria. That is why I said, at the start of my remarks, that I would have welcomed some support from Senator Carr on this issue.

PARA.TAB: How does the management of the bank respond? To show how out of touch the bank remains, the managing director, David Murray, attacks complaints that decision making has become too centralised in Sydney. He is quoted as saying that this is a symptom of Melbourne's parochial nature. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is frustrating because we don't look at ourselves as being a Sydney bank; we look at ourselves as a distinctly Australian bank. It is an issue for us.

Of course, Mr Murray may not consider the Commonwealth Bank a Sydney bank, but it might help if he put himself in the shoes of other people outside of Sydney. Better still, he might put some of his top management outside of Sydney. Virtually all decision making is now done in the Sydney headquarters. Of the Commonwealth Bank's 23 executives, 17 are in Sydney and just one is in Melbourne. The CBA has a significant proportion of its assets in Melbourne; apparently one-quarter of its loan portfolio is in Victoria. But Victoria, as I said, has only one of the 23 senior executives.

PARA.TAB: The merged CBA has clearly lost ground in Victoria as a result of employee and customer disenchantment. In December 1990, the Commonwealth plus the State Bank of Victoria had 42.6 per cent of the housing loan market. By last October, that figure had slumped to 35 per cent. When the Commonwealth Bank acquired the State Bank, it inherited a 13 per cent share of the housing loan market worth $5.7 billion. It has, according to this week's BRW, effectively lost half of this. The excuse proffered by Mr Murray is totally unconvincing. He argues in the BRW article that the integration of the State Bank in the Commonwealth Bank caused disruption and `was bound to cost market share'.

However, at the time of the merger, the chairman of the bank, Mr Besley, said, `I can see the merger being effected smoothly without difficulty.' In short, the bank's management has squandered the significant gains it received as a result of the merger. Mr Besley should be sending a please explain note to the bank's management. It is time that the Commonwealth Bank told us precisely what its plans are. Despite the massive job losses, we read in the BRW article that there may be further substantial closures of branches, presumably resulting in further major losses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, the cabinet of the government is considering the question of greenhouse, and I just wish to make a few remarks on the importance of this issue. The earth's atmosphere is now changing more rapidly than at any time during the whole history of this planet. It is being changed because of the activities of human beings, particularly because of the burning of fossil fuel. We do not know exactly what the consequences of that will be, but the matter is serious and is regarded as such by most of the senior scientists who look at it. Indeed, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has thrice recommended that globally we need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent, simply to cause the level of gases such as carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to level off at approximately twice what they would have been had we maintained the level at the pre-industrial concentration. Nobody knows exactly what a doubling of CO(2) will do in terms of increased temperature, climate change and so on.

PARA.TAB: More than four years ago, the government adopted interim planning targets to get the reduction to 1990 levels and then get a 20 per cent reduction below that level by the year 2005. More than two years ago, in December 1992, the government, in its intergovernmental agreement on the environment with the state governments, said that it would adopt and adhere to the national greenhouse response strategy. I think the Senate needs to know and the people of Australia need to understand that nothing has happened either at state level or at federal level to actually implement that national greenhouse response strategy. So the meeting tonight is important. It is particularly important because it precedes by less than a month the meeting in Berlin at which countries will hopefully get locked down with some more certain strategies.

In the last few days, a booklet has appeared authored by Dr George Wilkenfeld of George Wilkenfeld and Associates—and those who know anything about the strategies for energy efficiency and the use of alternative energy would know that Dr Wilkenfeld has had a long and very credible history of work in this area—Dr Clive Hamilton of the Australia Institute and Dr Hugh Sadler, both of whom have a long history of association, Dr Clive Hamilton with the Resource Assessment Commission, and Hugh Sadler specifically in the area of energy efficiency and alternative energy. I would like to read into the record the comments of these three experts about the inadequacy of the government's response in relation to greenhouse. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Greenhouse Response Strategy (NGRS) agreed between the Commonwealth and the States has failed to make any impact on Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. After two years of its operation, there is no evidence that even one tonne of carbon emissions has been saved as a result of the NGRS. Moreover, Australia's excess of emissions over the target of the Framework Convention on Climate Change—to return to 1990 levels by the year 2000—is likely to be far greater than has been admitted by the Commonwealth Government.

Consequently, Australia has passed up substantial `no-regrets' gains in energy efficiency, and our ability to participate effectively in international efforts to tackle climate change has been seriously compromised. Indeed, if all countries adopt a position based on special pleading, as Australia appears to be doing, then the complex and difficult international negotiations to reach a feasible agreement could collapse—
and I think that is that particularly important remark in view of the Berlin meeting. They continue:

The threat of climate change is a global one, and all nations need to consider whether they will participate in global efforts to address it. A rational and prudent assessment of the risks means that governments, companies and individuals must all take steps to reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of those activities over which they have control.

The issue of global warming is a classic case of an `externality', that is, a cost associated with an activity that is not met by the producer or consumer. This, combined with the long-term nature of the greenhouse problem, will require that governments take the lead in developing the response framework and implementing policies to reduce emissions.

The failure of the NGRS derives from a failure of governments to show leadership, to reconcile conflicting policy objectives and to distinguish the public interest from narrow commercial interests. This has been compounded by a lack of knowledge of the energy market in parts of the bureaucracy, and a lack of informed public debate and scrutiny.

Nearly every major energy supply decision taken in Australia in the two years since the NGRS was adopted has favoured the option with the higher greenhouse gas emissions. In instances where governments have not themselves directly made the decisions, they have failed to give the decision makers concerned any signal that greenhouse gas emissions need serious consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are examples of that?

—An example would be, for instance, in the plans in relation to the state electricity utilities. There was a marvellous opportunity here, under this competition policy, to add that dimension to that policy. There was a marvellous opportunity to write energy efficiency into the car plan. They go on:

SPEECH.PARA: For the foreseeable future, the national gains from carefully targeted action will far exceed the national losses, and substantial greenhouse gas reductions can be achieved at zero or negative cost. The elements of a moderate but effective national greenhouse response strategy are—
and this is a point that I want to stress to government as it considers these matters—
.a commitment to build no further coal-fired power stations;
.a low level carbon tax to promote energy efficiency and renewables—
and, as far as the Democrats are concerned, all that money that is raised should be ploughed back into the economy to address efficiency and alternative energy sources—
.establishment of a Sustainable Energy Authority—
an actual authority that would promote these things within the bureaucracy and out in private industry—
.mandatory energy standards for equipment and buildings—
something we do not have: a national building code which takes account of planning considerations and building codes—
.a credible program to increase the fuel-efficiency of vehicles;
.integration of greenhouse policies with micro-economic reform policies in the energy sector;
.an end to land clearing—

something that fortunately the opposition has adopted in its statement that was put out by Mr McLachlan only a few weeks ago; and I hope that actually means that the opposition is not going to clear any more forests because it says in its policy that it is going to end land clearing—
.a clear strategy for transition to renewable energy use in the longer term; and
.adoption of feasible national greenhouse gas reduction targets.

I think those are a very credible, very achievable set of objectives which have been outlined by these three experts in the energy field. I would urge the government to carefully consider all those matters, both in its considerations this evening and as it goes forward to enter into negotiations with other governments at the Berlin meeting in March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is well aware of the fact that the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee is undertaking an inquiry into soccer football in Australia. As stated in an advertisement for the inquiry, its terms of reference are:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to inquire into the role of coaches, players, agents, clubs, officials, and others in the transfer of Australian sportspeople, and into any other matters relating to corruption, conflicts of interest, tax evasion, and improper financial transactions, with particular reference to the sport of soccer; and review the report by the Hon. D.G. Stewart to the Australian Soccer Federation; and that the Committee report to the Senate on this matter by 11 May 1995.
The committee invited persons and organisations, as stated further on in that advertisement:
. . . wishing to express views on matters relating to this reference to lodge written submissions (which may, if necessary, be made on a confidential basis) by 28 February 1995—
which is today. The advertisement also states:

The Committee will consider all submissions and may invite parties to give supporting evidence at public or in camera hearings. Proceedings of the Committee and its witnesses are protected by Parliamentary privilege. Submissions become the property of the Committee and are only made public after a decision by the Committee.

In other words, there is adequate protection for those people who want to give evidence to improve the standing of this sport by revealing some of the major problems that appear to be creating a great deal of difficulty in it. People will be provided with protection—protection that was not available to the Stewart inquiry, which revealed, nonetheless, a great many damaging matters. Those people who, like me, are very keen to see this sport emerge stronger, more effectively and better managed than it is at the moment would have hoped that many Australians involved in the sport of soccer or concerned about its welfare would have come forward.

PARA.TAB: By the close of business today, something like only 20 people had professed a willingness to give evidence to this committee. That strikes me as extraordinary but not unexpected, because evidence given to the committee by the players' union indicated to us that many players who were very concerned about what was happening to their sport and who had evidence of what they believed to be malpractice have been terrorised out of coming forward to give evidence because of their concern about their future in the game so long as various administrators and coaches who are there remain there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this to the parliamentary committee?

—This is to the parliamentary committee, yes. I repeat: only 20 people have come forward. I have received plenty of anonymous correspondence and many anonymous phone calls pointing me in some interesting directions in relation to corruption and conflicts of interest, and so on. But it is a matter of major concern to me that many people who can contribute important information to this inquiry have not come forward because they fear for their own futures in the sport either in their playing role or in their administrative role.

PARA.TAB: To an extent, this problem may well have been compounded by the fact that absolutely nothing has happened so far in response to the recommendations of the Stewart inquiry which was held by the ASF itself. In fact, one of the commissioners who stood aside during an inquiry into his involvement with the Marconi club—and that related to a Licensing Court hearing—and who was severely criticised in the Stewart report has, in fact, now resumed his membership of the Australian Soccer Federation, despite the fact of a very unfavourable report being made by the Licensing Court which has asked him to show cause why he should not be prevented from holding any club office for the next 10 years.

There is a failure to take action on the Stewart report. People are saying, `We will wait until the Senate committee report comes out.' To an extent, people are saying, `Wait until we see whether you should be run over by a 20-tonne truck or a five-tonne truck.' The Stewart report made some very strong recommendations. We will obviously be examining them. I fear that the decision by the ASF to not take action on the Stewart report until the Senate committee has responded diminishes the prospect of people coming forward to provide us with evidence, because they are concerned that nothing will be done.

I recommend to the ASF that the people who are criticised should at least be asked to step aside. Some kind of sanction should be applied, even if it is not the dismissal that Stewart recommended. Otherwise, we will have difficulty convincing people that there is merit in their coming forward to try to clean up this operation.

Another matter I want to raise is the general question of conflicts of interest. This matter affects quite a few sports, but none as dramatically as soccer, as has been shown. People should very closely examine it in terms of propriety. One might be a director of the Australian Soccer Federation Ltd. It is all very well to be involved in commercial transactions with it that are stated to be in the normal course of business. But there is always the suggestion that it is some kind of deal for the boys if one is involved in that way. That is why I raised this matter last year and suggested that the soccer inquiry be expanded to cover the question of conflicts of interest, which has been done.

I notice in the annual report of the Australian Soccer Federation, which was dealt with last weekend at its annual meeting, that two transactions once again relate to directors of the federation. One of them, Mr Constantine, has since resigned. He is the principal of Constantine & Co Solicitors which rendered legal advice to the economic entity; that is, the federation. All dealings were in the ordinary course of business and on normal commercial terms and conditions. Fees paid to Constantine & Co Solicitors during the year totalled $110,275.

There have been accusations on a commercial television station that some overcharging was involved in these fees. These allegations need answering. Perhaps a Senate inquiry may well be an appropriate place to answer them. It demonstrates how unwise it is for people involved in organisations like this one to also be involved in trading relationships with them.

Another was a director of the federation, Mr Anthony Labbozzetta. He has an interest as a partner in the business Marconi Travel. I understand that that interest is with his brother. This business renders services in connection with travel arrangements with the federation in respect of interstate and international travel. All dealings with the business are in the ordinary course of business and on normal commercial terms and conditions. Moneys paid to Marconi Travel during the year in respect of travel arrangements amounted to $235,102.

As the report says, these are normal business dealings. But, as I said, there is always this suggestion that those involved might get some special deal. I am not making that accusation. It is one of the natural consequences of this sort of thing. It is unfortunate for the ASF at this time that so many of the commissioners seem to have some commercial or financial relationship to the ASF.

I am told that another commissioner is a trade debtor to the ASF. I do not know on what terms or basis, but it is not disclosed in this report. It is certainly unfortunate. I hope that under the Senate inquiry all these question marks are resolved satisfactorily. One question mark, which is the role of coach Mr Rale Rasic, has been resolved, at least as far as his club is concerned. Mr Rasic was severely criticised in the Stewart report for allegedly requiring people to take out insurance policies in order to get into his club team. As I understand it, that club, Parramatta Eagles, has sacked Mr Rasic, but not on those grounds; it simply did so on the grounds that his coaching was not providing the club with enough wins. But this whole series of problems has to be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise three issues in relation to the production of chicken meat in Australia. I raise these issues under three headings: public health; genetic engineering; and animal welfare. In relation to this matter, I draw the attention of the Senate to the very informative annual report of the Chicken Meat Research and Development Council for 1993-94. I will refer to that report because it is very germane to the issues that I wish to speak about.

PARA.TAB: It is important that the critical nature of public health issues is being recognised at last. The terrible outbreak of disease which occurred recently in Adelaide through the consumption of processed meat goods shows how vital it is to have the highest standards in this area. The smallest lapse in standards can have very tragic outcomes.

I recently met with representatives from the Chicken Growers Association in Queensland. They raised some matters with me which cause apprehension. They raised concerns about the potential problems in ensuring that high health standards are maintained in light of the loosening restrictions accompanying the adoption of the GATT agreement.

Recently, Senator Boswell asked a question of Senator Collins in this place about the importation of chicken meat into Australia. In his answer, Senator Collins assured the Senate that AQIS has developed a protocol for the importation of chicken meat and that this protocol is the best in the world. I suggest that an even better solution to the best protocols in the world is to not import chicken meat at all.

Recently, I met with representatives of AQIS. They did not disagree with me when I put to them that if we did not import chicken meat we would not need either protocols to prevent disease or to raise the apprehension of Australian people about the importation of disease. I will quote from this report the concerns raised about public health issues. They demonstrate the depth of these concerns. Page 23 of the report, under the heading `Public health', reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Research and development in this area has the objective of improving measures to safeguard public health. To achieve this objective, Council recognises the need to support research and development to:
.identify ways to reduce the dissemination of Salmonella, Campylobacter and Listeria in the processing, handling and storage environments.
Certainly those representatives of the Chicken Growers Association who came to me underlined the great dangers inherent in importing chicken meat into Australia in terms of these health risks.

PARA.TAB: I will go a little further. My whole philosophy of life is that people ought to grow their own food. That in itself is worthy of debate in this place. I will not engage in such a debate tonight, but I certainly intend to engage in it at another time.

It is true that any exports should be in excess of domestic needs and should be in those markets where there is a real need to feed people who are unable to feed themselves. This philosophy does not extend to the importation of chicken meat into Australia. We can supply all the chicken meat we need from our own domestic industry. Why take the risk? It is simply not worth it.

Let me turn to the issue of genetic engineering. Concerns are repeatedly expressed by ethicists, scientists, church groups and environmentalists about the dangers and undesirability of genetic engineering. I concede it is a vexed issue rather than a simple black-and-white matter. Nonetheless, I believe insufficient consideration has been given to the many matters involved.

Again, the chicken industry is no exception. Page 55 of the same report details research into introducing certain genes into embryonic cells with an eye to improving growth and production characteristics of chickens. I read again from this report to underline the nature of this research. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ability to genetically engineer poultry is dependent on two major steps, (1) to establish a means by which genes of interest can be introduced into suitable embryonic cells and (2) to be able to culture those cells containing the introduced gene to produce a chimeric embryo through to hatching. This project aims to address both of these steps.

There is growing concern about the necessity for this kind of intervention, and legislation to regulate or even take account of this kind of genetic engineering is way behind the development of scientific techniques. The public debate, in terms of this kind of genetic engineering, is indeed out of sight. What is evident from representations I have had is that Australian consumers do not need, nor do they desire, to eat food genetically engineered in this manner.

PARA.TAB: I turn finally to the issue of animal welfare. Animal welfare issues have become more significant in the public consciousness in recent times. The use of animals for food production is one of the focal points of such concerns. Whilst chicken meat production generally does not have the horrendous problems still associated with battery hens used in egg production, there are still animal welfare issues which need to be addressed.

The report I have referred to tonight details some research into improving bird welfare, but it is predominantly motivated by a wish to improve productivity. Two projects are outlined in the report. One is aimed at identifying and reducing human behaviour which causes fear in chickens, and the other project is aimed at ensuring that broiler sheds are maintained at optimum temperatures to reduce heat stress for the chickens and to improve their productivity.

The Australian Democrats are grateful for these initiatives. They are certainly in the right direction. However, much remains to be done before the Democrats will be convinced that the humane treatment of other animals produced for eating has reached an acceptable level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let it pass without comment that we now know the Australian Democrats' trade policy in relation to primary produce. As stated by Senator Woodley tonight, the Democrat trade policy, or at least his trade policy, is this: we should not export primary produce from this country unless it is, first, surplus to our domestic requirements and, secondly, the people to whom we send it are incapable of producing it themselves. That is a remarkable policy because, at best, it reduces Australian farmers to being unpaid aid merchants for other countries. If people cannot afford to produce the primary produce themselves, the food themselves, it stands to reason they cannot afford to pay for it. If they cannot afford to pay for it, heaven knows why we would want to produce it.

PARA.TAB: Farming in this country relies on people being able to make a profit, yet Senator Woodley would deny our farmers and our primary producers the opportunity to make a profit because we are allowed to do things only for charity. That is Senator Woodley's policy. If one were more charitable, one could say maybe Senator Woodley means something else—but not on the words he used. Quite clearly, the Japanese could say that they will not accept Australian beef because they can produce their own beef in Japan. That would completely overlook the fact that the Japanese would be producing the beef for their domestic requirements at three or four times the price of the beef that we ship to Japan because they would be closing the market and there would be an excess of demand over supply—but that is a consequence of what Senator Woodley said in his remarks. Senator Woodley had ample time to consider what he has had to say. Senator Woodley came in here to make a statement. He carefully thought it out; it was all written down. That is the Democrat trade policy.

Next time the Democrats get up in this parliament or outside this parliament and say they are the great friends of the primary producers of this country, let it be on the record that we know what their real policy is. Their real policy is to reduce primary producers to being unpaid aid merchants, to reduce this country generally to a subsistence standard of living and to turn back the clock to the 19th century. As far as I am concerned, that policy belongs with people from the 19th century. Maybe Senator Woodley is the only person who would rationally expound such a view in this place today.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to short-term United States (US) expatriates working in Australia: under the Superannuation Guarantee Charge (SGC) legislation certain categories of employees qualify for exemption. Included in these exemptions are holders of executive (overseas) visas or entry permits (code number 413) Granted under the Australian migration regulations. These visas are generally issued to persons working in a capacity which an Australian resident would not be qualified; however, the great majority of US expatriates working in Australia hold different classes of visas, for example, 414 (specialist overseas), 442 (occupational trainee) or 411 (exchange) which are not exempted from the SGC:

(1) Is it a fact that, under US law, SGC contributions made on behalf of these expatriates will be subject to US tax in the year of contribution, and income derived from the investment of these contributions will be subject to US tax as it accrues, unless the fund in which they are made into can comply with certain US requirements, which is highly unlikely. In addition, due to the operation of the Australia/US Double Taxation Agreement, is it a fact that a full tax credit for Australian taxes paid on eligible termination payments made to the expatriate may not be available.

(2) Given also that the continued membership in a US retirement plan for a US expatriate is dependent upon, amongst other things, not receiving retirement funding from a foreign affiliate, and that contributions made under the SGC may cause the expatriate to lose eligibility for membership of the US retirement plan, will the Government consider exempting these visa holders as it has already done to holders of class 413 executive (overseas) visas and entry permits and, as has been indicated by the Assistant Treasurer, non-residents who receive prize money.
(3) Is the Treasurer aware of any expatriates other than from the US working on a short-term basis in Australia facing similar difficulties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) While interpretation of US tax laws is ultimately a matter for the US authorities, it appears that certain Australian "pension plans" may be entitled to concessions under the US tax laws, including exemption of fund income and deferral of employee's tax on employer contributions until benefits are paid. There are a number of requirements limiting contributions and benefits, commencement of benefits and minimum distributions which must be met for a pension plan to qualify for these concessions. In the absence of specific details it is not possible to say whether particular superannuation schemes might qualify for those concessions under US tax laws.

Under Article 22(1) of the Australian/US Double Tax Convention, the US provides a credit to US residents or citizens for the "appropriate amount of income taxes paid to Australia". This credit is provided subject to the limitations of the law of the US. One possible limitation is that (as with Australian law) the amount of the foreign tax credit is limited to the US tax that would otherwise be payable on the foreign income. It should also be noted that, where expatriate US residents consider actions of either country have resulted in taxation not in accordance with the Convention, they may present their case to "competent" authorities who will try to resolve the problem.

(2) Whether or not superannuation contributions made to satisfy the SGC arrangements would disentitle US expatriates to continued membership in a US retirement plan is a matter for US authorities and/or the relevant US retirement plan to determine.

It is relevant, nevertheless, that the Government has appointed an independent committee to review policies and procedures governing the temporary entry for work of business personnel into Australia. In December 1994, the Committee released a draft report which included, inter alia, a proposal to collapse into one visa sub-class all business temporary residents; ie those presently entering Australia under visa sub-classes 411 (exchange), 412 (independent executive), 413 (executive (overseas) (employed)) and 414 (specialist), and to exempt them from the SGC. The report calls for public submissions on its proposals to be made by 24 February 1995.

The Government will consider any recommendations the Committee may make in this area in its final report, due by June 1995. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has, in its Fifteenth Report, also made a recommendation in this general area, to which the Government will respond. In considering proposals to exempt further categories of temporary residents, the Government will be concerned to avoid the possibility of such exemptions giving rise to labour market distortions, especially once the SGC contribution rate rises to 9 per cent.

In the meantime, to the extent that the existing policy gives rise to any particular taxation and other difficulties in the home countries of persons affected, these matters are best pursued with the relevant authorities in those countries by the expatriates concerned. It will also remain the case, of course, that temporary entrants to Australia may withdraw any superannuation contributions made on their behalf on permanently departing the country.
(3) The Government has received a number of representations about the application of the SGC to

ANSWER.PARA: the expatriates of other countries. These representations have not, however, alluded to similar taxation and pension plan issues as have been raised by the honourable senator in respect of US expatriates.
