(5) What is the purpose of the Health Communication Network.
(6) How many staff are employed in the Health Communication Network.
(7) How long has the Commonwealth of Australia been the owner of the Health Communication Network.
(8) What was the Health Communication Network before being purchased by the Commonwealth of Australia.
(9) What other costs have been incurred with the purchase of this particular business name.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Health Communication Network (HCN) is an initiative of Health Ministers, both State and Commonwealth. The HCN sets out to improve the flow of health information in a safe, secure and effective manner.
The HCN was first discussed in 1991 at a Health and Telecommunications Industry workshop sponsored by Health Ministers.
Since 1992, the HCN project has undertaken consultations, studies and demonstration projects to provide tangible and supportable evidence of the uses and benefits of the HCN.

In July 1993 Australian Health Ministers agreed to the establishment of the HCN as a company by 1994 with an independent board. A company was considered the most appropriate vehicle because the health sector has clearly indicated it does not feel comfortable with Government, neither Commonwealth nor State, dealing with its information and secondly, the Health Communication Network is to be set up on commercial grounds.

The development and implementation of the Health Communication Network has to date been funded by the Commonwealth Government ($1.8m in 92-93, $2.0m in 1993-94 and an estimated $6.6m in 1994-96). The Health Communication Network company will repay the costs associated with its infrastructure development and operational subsidy—approximately $7.0m.
The HCN will be established as a company in January 1995, with a board reflecting expertise in health, business and communications.
Initial services and the networking capability of the HCN are currently being built with the commencement of services in early 1995.
These services include:
Poisons Information Centres (PICs): access to any PIC around Australia via a single national number. This will enable faster and easier access to poisons information.
Pathology results reporting service: to enable the timely and safe delivery of pathology reports to the medical community.

Hospitals and community services: a communications service linking hospitals with general practitioners and community nurses to provide access to information such as discharge summaries, pathology results, radiology services or specific disease protocol management.

Organisational support: an E-mail based service to enable health professionals to exchange or access information. It may include a range of functions from simple bulletin board access, individual forums for specialist groups, facilities for storing and exchanging documents, and access to information services such as the Internet.

When it came time to commence the action of setting up the company it was found that a company called `Health Communications Network' (with an `s') was already operating and had been for a number of years.

The Commonwealth was advised that it could infringe S52 of the Trade Practices Act if it were to register `Health Communication Network' knowing there was a company with a similar name, geographic location and market segment.

The Attorney-General's Department advised that the Department of Human Services and Health should take action to remove the similarity and compensate the existing company for it to change its name and then reserve the name.

The purchase was then necessary for the Commonwealth to secure the name of Health Communication Network as it is already widely accepted by the health sector and to change the name and re-establish under another name would have been costly and very confusing for the users of the HCN.
The amount paid to Health Communications Network for them to forfeit their name was based on the stock they had on hand and a component of goodwill for readvertising, logos etc.

(3) The legal costs associated with the purchase of this business name were $7,002.50 to the Attorney-General's Department for the Commonwealth's legal fees and $1,750.00 for the Health Communications Network legal fees.
(4) Clarke and Company were contracted to develop and draft a business plan for the Health Communication Network company.

The business plan incorporates a marketing strategy, operations strategy, human resources strategy, finance strategy, implementation strategy, a proposed organisation structure, initial services and financial projections.
The business plan is still in draft form as it will be taken up and completed by the company on its formation.
(5) The purpose of the Health Communication Network is to provide communication services which will assist in improving quality of care and productivity in the health sector.

The health sector is very dependent on information. Extensive fieldwork undertaken in the development phase clearly identified the areas where health care workers are dissatisfied with the lack of timely information, and where patients suffer from delays in treatment, lack of co-ordination, or duplicated tests. These are the areas that the HCN will be concentrating on initially.

The Health Communication Network combines expertise in health and telecommunications to tailor services appropriate for the health sector. The HCN approach is to work closely with health care workers to identify the issues and design services using the appropriate technology.

The HCN has developed an Ethical and Policy Framework in conjunction with privacy, health and consumer experts. The principles that govern the communication of health information, as well as codes of practice to give effect to these principles, will be encapsulated in the company's Memorandum and Articles of Association. Codes of practice, privacy safeguards, and the formation of a Privacy Advisory Panel are also featured in the Framework.

(6) The Health Communication Network is currently operating as a section within the Department of Human Services and Health pending the set up of the company and it has eight staff members, with five permanent Commonwealth officers and three temporary staff members.

(7) The Commonwealth has developed the Health Communication Network. It has had a long period of development and was first discussed in 1991 at a Health and Telecommunications Industry workshop sponsored by Health Ministers as described in (1).
(8) The Health Communication Network was developed by the Commonwealth. See answer to (1).
(9) There have been no further costs except those already mentioned ($60,000 purchase price and $8,752.50 legal fees).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) How many submissions have been received to date by the Industry Commission for its inquiry into charitable organisations; and (b) how many of these submissions were from organisations representing ethnic communities.

(2) (a) Has the Minister seen the report by the Ethnic Communities' Council of New South Wales entitled Equity, Efficiency and the Industry Commission; (b) is the Minister aware that the Ethnic Communities' Council has expressed concern that the Industry Commission has not adequately informed ethnic community organisations of the significance of the Commission's inquiry into charitable organisations; (c) does the Minister agree with the Council's concern that the Industry Commission is not adequately implementing the requirements of the Commonwealth Government's Access and Equity Strategy; (d) what steps have been taken to ensure that the Industry Commission adequately discharges its responsibilities under the Access and Equity Strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) A total of 447 submissions were received by the Industry Commission in relation to the Charitable Organisations inquiry prior to the release of the Draft Report on 27 October 1994. In addition, the Commission visited or met 157 organisations in Australia during the above period.

(b) Those making submissions were not asked to specify the groups which they represented. Therefore, it is not possible to identify precisely those submissions which are particular to organisations representing ethnic communities. Eighty-five submissions make at least some reference to ethnic issues. Of these, twenty-six claim to, at least to some extent, represent ethnic groups or target services to ethnic groups. Six submissions were from organisations which appear to have ethnic communities as their primary focus.

The inability to identify precisely the representation of organisations also applies to those groups with which the Commission held discussions. Five of the organisations visited appeared to have migrant or ethnic communities as their primary focus. Many other meetings, such as those with the State Councils of Social Service, were with peak groups which included organisations focused on ethnic communities, and many organisations visited had general or specialist programs which provided services to ethnic communities. The author of the report referred to by Senator Woodley, for example, was present at one of the meetings with the New South Wales Council of Social Service.
(2) (a) Yes.

(b) Yes. However, the Commission has undertaken an extensive information dissemination program in relation to the Charitable Organisations inquiry. This comprised components aimed at the general community, of which ethnic groups are a part, and elements targeted specifically at ethnic groups. Separate advertisements announcing the inquiry and the hearing dates and venues were placed in all major metropolitan newspapers. Shortly after the inquiry was announced, Commissioners addressed briefing meetings convened by the Councils of Social Service, and which included representatives of the ethnic community. Commissioners and staff also completed a large number of subsequent print and radio interviews, speaking engagements and visits to promote awareness of the inquiry, including visits to ethnic groups. An interested party list of over 1700 individuals and organisations has been kept fully informed of the progress of the inquiry.

(c) The Industry Commission has noted the concerns of the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales in relation to the Commission's implementation of the Commonwealth Government's Access and Equity Strategy. While there may be room for improvement in procedures for making contact with members of these target groups, the methodology used in the report referred to by Senator Woodley is questionable in that the findings appear to be strongly based on a desk study of Commission reports. This style of assessment involved a basic count of submissions received and presentations made at hearings across a small number of Inquiries. It appears not to account for the very extensive public consultation, through industry visits and discussions with interested parties, which forms part of Commission inquiries.

It also appears that there was little consultation by the author of the report with external agencies which have had involvement with the Commission's inquiry process. Furthermore, no input was sought from the Commission at any stage of the preparation of this report.

(d) The Commission has engaged a consultant to review and assess the effectiveness of its implementation of the Access and Equity Strategy, and to make recommendations as to how its processes might be improved. The consultant's report is due in early 1995. The Commission will give careful consideration to any recommendations to determine if, and how, its inquiry processes can be improved.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 13 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the leadbeater's possum, which is listed under the Commonwealth Threatened Species Act and is found only in the mountain ash forests of the Victorian central highlands, can an assurance be given that the Government will be refusing to issue export woodchip licences for areas known to be the habitat for leadbeater's possum at least until an adequate and comprehensive management plan for the species has been developed and agreed to by the Commonwealth Nature Conservation Agency.

(2) Will old-growth forests in Nixon block and Stony Creek block in East Gippsland be woodchipped by Harris Daishowa in the coming year; if so, given that these areas have been clearly defined as of high conservation value warranting protection under the moratorium clause of the National Forest Policy, what action is being taken to protect them from being destroyed before they can be protected by placing strong conditions on woodchip licences for 1995.
(3) What conditions will be placed on woodchip licences for these areas for 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Midway Wood Products Pty Ltd has been granted approval to export woodchips sourced from the central highlands area of Victoria. Before renewing the company's export licence I satisfied myself that the approval of the proposal was consistent with the Commonwealth's Endangered Species Protection Act.

I understand that the main habitat for leadbeater's possum is old-growth forest. I am advised that the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) has excluded leadbeater's possum habitat from logging. In addition, I understand the central highlands is continuing to be surveyed for leadbeater's possum habitat and that there are cooperative arrangements between DCNR and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency for the recovery of the species.

I would also note that the DCNR has put in place measures for ensuring that adverse impacts on leadbeater's possum are ameliorated or avoided under the State's Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act. In issuing the licence I have included licence conditions which require the exporter to comply with Victorian Government requirements and ensure that export operations do not threaten species and communities listed under the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.

(2) As the Prime Minister announced on 2 February 1995, the Commonwealth has put in place a process for assessing the conservation values of the 509 coupes identified as requiring further consideration before logging proceeds. Consistent with this process I have identified 57 coupes which satisfy the criteria for logging to continue. The remainder will now be assessed in accordance with the 8 week assessment process outlined in the Prime Minister's Statement. Export approval will not be granted for woodchips sourced from these coupes, including some in Nixon and Stoney Creek blocks in East Gippsland, unless it is assessed that they would not be required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

I also understand that in East Gippsland at least 60 per cent of the old-growth form of all forest types harvested are protected from logging, with the less common types having greater protection (up to 100 per cent in some cases).
(3) All export licences require the exporter to give due regard to the environment and include conditions requiring that the exporter—

not carry out logging of pulpwood intended for export as woodchips in, or export woodchips produced from logs removed from, an area which has been entered on the Register of the National Estate or placed on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate unless the exporter has received prior written notice from the Minister or the Department that logging can take place in that particular area;

comply with the requirements of the relevant State Government and all relevant local authorities to ensure that all operations connected with the export of hardwood woodchips under this licence are conducted so as to prevent significant impacts on the environment;

shall ensure that any of its operations conducted in association with activities approved under this licence do not threaten with extinction, or significantly impede the recovery of, a native species listed in Schedule 1 or an ecological community listed in Schedule 2 of the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992; and
report on compliance with licence conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Federal government provide Aboriginal communities with any resources or similar assistance specifically to help them monitor communicable diseases within their communities.
(2) What is being done to curb the rising incidence of HIV and STD infection among the Aboriginal people of northern Australia, particularly those in the Kimberley region of Western Australia?

(3) Given that the department states in the estimates hearings of 17 November 1994 that there are rising numbers of HIV positive Aborigines, there must be figures to reflect this; if so, what are the details of such information.

(4) How does the Federal government propose to apply its national strategy on AIDS in regions such as the Kimberley if it does not maintain data on the rate of infection among the many Aboriginal communities there, especially when the rate of infection is overtaking the national rate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In November 1992, the Commonwealth entered into joint arrangements with the governments of South Australia, Northern Territory and Western Australia to establish a new service for Aboriginal people in the Tri-State region. One aspect of this project is to monitor the health status of Aboriginal people in relation to Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV. The monitoring of communicable diseases in Australia is done by the States and Territories.

(2) Under the first National HIV/AIDS Strategy in 1989-90, nearly $2.5 million was approved under the Commonwealth AIDS Prevention and Education (CAPE) Program and the Commonwealth AIDS Workforce Information Standard and Exchange (CAWISE) Program for projects specifically targeting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The second National HIV/AIDS Strategy 1993-94 to 1995-96 specifically identifies Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as a high priority for HIV/AIDS/STD education and prevention. Additional Commonwealth funds of $9 million over three years have been offered to States and Territories, with no matching requirement, under the Special Funding Program for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander HIV/AIDS/STD initiatives. The guidelines for the Special Funding Program, which were developed in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, are based upon the principles of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander consultation, participation and empowerment.

In 1994-95 Western Australia received an allocation of $787,000 from the Special Funding Program, the Northern Territory received $638,991 and Queensland received $1,219,336. Most of the projects conducted in Queensland targeted the Northern region of that state, with many projects being undertaken in the Cape York and Torres Strait regions. In Western Australia the single largest grant was for $396,200 and aimed to develop skilled and equipped teams of health workers and public health nurses to provide clinical and prevention and education services within four regions in remote Western Australia.

Some gaps in current strategies for HIV/AIDS and STD education and prevention for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were identified and nearly $465,000 was approved under the National Priorities Program 1993-94 for 5 projects which aimed to address these gaps. Included in this was $102,688 to the Kimberly Medical Service to support a tour of their theatre group's play on HIV/AIDS, "No Prejudice". This project was developed in close consultation with the Kimberley Aboriginal community.

(3) National data on the number of cases of HIV is collected, however, in keeping with the wishes of the Aboriginal communities information regarding the Aboriginality of cases is not reported at a national level. However, from informal information provided by States and Territories the Department had been made aware of the trends in the incidence of HIV in the Aboriginal population.

(4) The Commonwealth will continue to liaise closely with States/Territories and local Aboriginal community groups and ensure that appropriate implementation of the National HIV/AIDS Strategy takes place in Aboriginal communities. Whether communities are at more or less risk does not alter the necessity to convey consistent messages about risk taking behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article in the Australian on 10 February 1995 entitled `Diggers may join peacekeeping force in Angola':
(1) Has Australia been officially approached by the United Nations (UN) seeking our participation in a peacekeeping force in Angola.
(2) What preparations or planning have already been undertaken by the Australian Defence Force (ADF) in anticipation of joining a UN peacekeeping operation in Angola.
(3) Outline the conditions under which ADF personnel would be committed to a UN peacekeeping force in Angola.
(4) (a) How many ADF personnel may be sent to Angola under UN auspices; and (b) will members of the army, navy or air force be sent to Angola.

(6) Who would have command and control of ADF personnel deployed to Angola, including participation in peacekeeping and other operational activities.
